li.p: Syntactic constraints on extraction and P-stranding
A syntactic reanalysis account for P-stranding
The government and Case property of lexical heads
P-stranding under A-bar-movement in German and Dutch
D-to-P incorporation from the specifier position

subsection.heading: 1 Introduction
subsection.p: Ross (1986: 138) uses the term ‘preposition stranding’ (henceforth, P-stranding, to include cases of stranding of postpositions) to refer to cases where a preposition is stranded as a result of its object having been extracted, as illustrated in the English examples in (1) and (2):

(1)
a. Which booki have they talked about ti ?
b. Which carpeti did they step on ti ?

(2)
a. That booki has been talked about ti .
b. This carpeti was stepped on ti .

Extraction of the sort in (1) generally shows different properties than that in (2), and has come to be known as A-bar-movement, in distinction from the latter, which has been given the name A-movement.

From a typological perspective, languages exhibit a range of variation with respect to P-stranding. On the one extreme lie languages like English and Scandinavian, where P-stranding is possible under both A- and A-bar-movement:

(3)
a. Vadi
talade du om ti ? Swedish
what talked you about
‘What did you talk about?’
b. Denna bok blev talad om ti
this book become talked about
‘This book has been talked about.’
On the other extreme are languages like Romance, where P-stranding is simply impossible in general: 1

(4)
a. *Qi ′as-tu parlé de ti ? French
what have-you talked about
b. *Chei
hai parlato di ti ? Italian
what have-you talked about
‘What did they talk about?’

(5)
a. *Ce livrei
a été parlé de ti . French
this book has been talked about
‘This book has been talked about.’
b. *Questo libro è stato parlato di ti . Italian
this book has been talked about
‘This book has been talked about.’

Somewhere in between these two extremes are Dutch and colloquial German, where movement of an R-pronoun (German wo ‘where/what’ and da ‘it’; Swiss German waas ‘what’; Dutch er ‘there/it’, daar ‘there’, waar ‘where/what’, ergens ‘something’, nergens ‘nothing’, and overal ‘all’) stranding P is possible: 2

(6)
a. Woi /*Wasi
redest du von ti ? German
what talk you from
‘What are you talking about?’
b. Waari /*Wati
heb je op ti
gerekend? Dutch
what have you on
counted
‘What have you counted on?’

(7)
a. Da/*Dieses Buchi
wurde von ti
geredet. German
it/this book became about
talked
‘It/this book has been talked about.’
b. Daar/*deze man is op ti
gerekend. Dutch
it/this man is on
counted
‘It/this man has been counted on.’

To my knowledge, there are no languages that allow P-stranding under A-movement, but not under A-bar-movement. At least superficially, then, the four logical possibilities for P-stranding can be summarized in (8):

(8)
P-stranding under A-movement P-stranding under A-bar-movement
+ + English
− − Romance
+ − ?
− + German/Dutch/Scandinavian

But as we will see, P-stranding under A-movement in German and Dutch and Scandinavian languages is only apparent; there are fairly good reasons to think in fact it falls under A-bar-movement. If this is correct, then languages either allow P-stranding or not, with type of movement being irrelevant.

From the grammatical theory perspective, the patterns of variation with respect to P-stranding in (8) raise a fundamental theoretical question as to what grammatical principles sanction P-stranding. An adequate answer to this question must shed light not only on the empirical question of whether P-stranding correlates with other grammatical properties, but also on the conceptual issue of whether the type of movement should bear on P-stranding.

In what follows I will examine these issues closely and argue that there is no grammatical principle specifically sanctioning P-stranding. Rather, P-stranding is related to the independent grammatical property of D incorporating into P. It thus does not bear on the type of movement, i.e., A- vs. A-bar, but is contingent on D not incorporating into P. The table in (8) thus gives a skewed impression of P-stranding under A-bar-movement being more common than P-stranding under A-movement, but in fact has no independent theoretical significance. It is simply a reflection of the general grammatical principles and other properties in particular languages that make P-stranding possible.

subsection.heading: 2 Syntactic constraints on extraction and P-stranding
subsection.p: Van Riemsdijk (1978a: 160) suggests that P-stranding as a result of extraction is subject to the same general constraint on extraction in (9):

(9)
The Head Constraint (HC):
No rule may involve Xi /Xj and Yi /Yj in the structure
(where H is the phonologically specified (i.e., non-null) head and Hn is the maximal projection of H (H¢¢¢ in our framework))
Thus, movement out of PPs, like out of other categories, must move through the Spec position to avoid a violation of the HC if the head H is non-empty (cf. also Koopman and Sportiche 1991b).
In Dutch, R-pronouns must appear to the left of Ps, while non-R-pronouns like hem ‘him’ die ‘that one’, and wie ‘who’ must appear to the right (Van Riemsdijk 1978a: 37):

(10)
a. erop/*oper ‘on it’; daarop/*opdaar ‘on there’
b. op hem/*hem op ‘on him’, op wie/*wie op ‘on whom’

If we take the left-complement of a P as appearing in the [Spec, PP] position (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1978a; Corver 1990), then we would expect that from the perspective of the HC R-pronouns may be extracted out of PPs, stranding Ps. The expectation is borne out by the facts:

(11)
a. Ik had niet [PP eri
[op ti ]] gerekend. Dutch
I had not it on counted
‘I had not counted on it.’
b. Ik had eri niet [PP ti [op ti ]] gerekend.

Moreover, if movement is further subject to the structure-preserving constraint (SPC, Emonds 1976: 5) restricting movement of a phrase to a position where it can be generated independently, then non-R-pronouns may not use the [Spec, PP] as escape hatch for extraction out of PP, since they cannot be independently generated there:

(12)
a. Ik had niet [PP
[op hem]] gerekend. Dutch
I had not
on him counted
b. *Ik had niet [PP hemi [op ti ]] gerekend.
c. *Ik had hemi niet [PP ti [op ti ]] gerekend.

The same explanation can be given for the lack of P-stranding in Romance. The complement of P never appears to the left of P, i.e., it never shows up in the [Spec, PP], as shown in the ungrammatical contrast in (13):

(13)
a. J’ai parlé à Jean. French
I have talked to Jean
‘I talked to John.’
b. *J’ai parlé Jean à.
Therefore, movement of the complement of P, stranding P, would violate either the SPC if it moves through [Spec, PP], or the HC if it moves directly out of PP:

(14)
a. *Quii
as-tu parlé [PP
[à [ti ]]? French
who have-you talked
to
‘Who did you talk to?’
b. *Quii as-tu parlé [PP ti [à [ti ]]?

Given these P-stranding facts in Dutch and French, it must be the case that in English when a wh-phrase object of a P is extracted, it moves through [Spec, PP] so as not to violate the HC. From the perspective of the SPC, a question that immediately arises is whether there is independent evidence showing that a wh-phrase may be independently generated in [Spec, PP]. Van Riemsdijk (1978a: 226ff) argues that Sluicing (Ross 1986) is evidence that a wh-phrase may independently appear in [Spec, PP]:

(15)
a. John left, but I don't know [PP whoi [with ti ]].
b. Mary bought some apples, but I don't know [PP whati [for ti ]].

If this is correct, then it is just as expected that a wh-phrase may move out of PP using [Spec, PP] as escape hatch. But it is far from obvious that the wh-phrase in (15) is in the [Spec, PP] position since it depends very much on the derivation and representation of Sluicing. We need not consider in detail the analysis of Sluicing in order to see that the examples in (15) do not in fact constitute evidence that wh-phrases may independently be generated in [Spec, PP].
The verb know may take either a DP or a CP complement, but, crucially, not a PP complement:

(16)
a. I knew John.
b. I knew when John was in the class.
c. *I knew in the class.

So there is no reason to think that the verb know takes a PP complement in (15). It is therefore clear that the syntactic structure of the example in (15) would be either as in (17a) where who is in the Spec of the PP headed by with in [Spec, CP] or as in (17b) where the PP headed by with is in argument position and its argument who is extracted to [Spec, CP] (the . . . indicates possible material that is not relevant to our discussion here):

(17)
a. John left, but I don't know [CP [PP whoi [with ti ]]j [[IP . . . tj ]]].
b. John left, but I don't know [CP whoi [[IP . . . [PP with ti ]]]].

The representation in (17b) is not relevant to Van Riemsdijk's claim that wh-phrases may be independently generated in [Spec, PP], since the wh-phrase is not in [Spec, PP]. 3 The relevant structure is the one in (17a). If this representation is the correct structure for the Sluicing construction, then we should expect that PPs with a non-bare wh-phrase are possible in the same position and that PPs with a bare wh-phrase in its Spec are also possible elsewhere. These expectations are not borne out by the facts, however. As shown in (18), non-bare wh-phrases are not possible in the Sluicing context:

(18)
a. *John left with some students, but I don't know [PP which onesi [with [ti ]]].
(cf. John left with some students, but I don't know with which ones)
b. *Mary brought in these books, but I don't know [PP which classi [for [ti ]]].
(cf. Mary brought in some books, but I don't know for which class)

If a bare wh-phrase is possible in [Spec, PP] as in (17a), then it is unclear why a non-bare wh-phrase may not occur in the same position. Furthermore, if we take the examples in (18) as evidence that non-bare wh-phrases may not be base-generated in [Spec, PP], then a problem arises as to how they may nevertheless be extracted without violating the HC, if they cannot use [Spec, PP] as escape hatch:

(19)
a. Which ones/studentsi did John leave [PP ti [with ti ]]?
b. Which classi did Mary bring in these books [PP ti [for ti ]]?
The grammatical contrast in (20) shows clearly that a PP with a bare wh-phrase in its Spec is not possible elsewhere, casting some doubts on the claim that the wh-phrases in (15) occur in [Spec, PP]:

(20)
a. *[PP whoi [with ti ]]j did John go out last night tj ?
b. [PP with whom]j did John go out last night tj ?

Although the grammatical contrast between (15a) and (20a) does not shed much light on the analysis of Sluicing (cf. also n. 3), it seems clear that the examples in (15) by themselves are not compelling evidence for wh-phrases being (possibly) base-generated in [Spec, PP].
A problem of a different sort also arises in Dutch, where a non-R-pronoun appearing to the left of a P may sometimes be extracted:

(21)
a. Je zei dat hij [PP
de boom in] geklommen is. Dutch
you said that he
the tree in climbed is
‘You said that he climbed into that tree.’
b. Welke boomk
zei je dat hij [PP tk
in] geklommen is?
which tree said you that he
in climbed is
‘Which tree did you say that he climbed into?’

There is an issue as to where the complement de boom occurs, specifically, whether it appears in the complement position of the P in ‘in’, i.e., a postposition, or it occurs in the [Spec, PP] position, having moved leftward from the complement position, i.e., in ‘in’ is a preposition:

(22)
a. . . . [PP [[DP de boom] in]] . . .
b. . . . [PP [DP de boom]i [in ti ]] . . .
But from the perspective of the HC it does not matter whether in is a pre-position or a postposition; extraction out of the PP is subject to the HC.
From the perspective of the HC, the wh-phrase welke boom ‘which tree’ in (21b) must be extracted through the [Spec, PP], either as in (23a) or as in (23b):

(23)
a. [DP welke boom]i . . . [PP ti [ti in]] . . .
b. [DP welke boom]i . . . [PP ti [in ti ]] . . .

But we see in (10) that non-R pronouns generally appear to the right of P, and are therefore not in [Spec, PP]. So non-R-pronoun wh-phrases may not be extracted through [Spec, PP], and extraction of the sort in (23) should be impossible. Van Riemsdijk (1978a) thus argues that in cases like (21) the P incorporates into V (Evers 1975b), as in (24):

(24)
a. Je zei dat hij [PP tj de boom] [inj +geklommen] is.
b. Welke boomk zei je dat hij [PP tj tk ] [inj +geklommen] is?
As a result, the head position of the PP is empty and the HC no longer applies; the wh-phrase in a PP whose head position is empty can now be extracted, observing the HC, as in (24b).

The idea that the P in in (21) incorporates into V apparently explains two facts. First, it explains why the complement of the P ends up being to the left of P, P having moved rightward as indicated in (24a). Second, it explains why the P may (optionally) raise together with V to the right of the auxiliary:

(25)
a. Je zei dat hij [PP de boom tj ] ti is [inj +geklommen]i .
‘You said that he climbed into that tree.’
b. Welke boomk zei je dat hij [PP tk tj ] ti is [inj +geklommen]i ?
‘Which tree did you say that he climbed into?’
But there are some facts that do not fall under this account. As shown in (26), the P is clearly not incorporated into V; yet, the wh-phrase may be extracted:

(26)
a. Welke boomk
klom Jan [PP
in tk ]?
which tree climbed Jan
into
‘Which tree did Jan climb into?’
b. Ik geloof dat Jan de boomk
gisteren [PP
in tk ] ti
is geklommeni .
I think that Jan the tree yesterday
in is climbed
‘I think that Jan climbed into that tree yesterday.’
c. Welke boomk
zei je dat hij [PP
in tk ] ti
is geklommeni ?
which tree said you that he
in is climbed
‘Which tree did you say that he climbed into?’

Here, the head of the PP is not empty. In addition, as non-R-pronouns may not be independently base-generated in the [Spec, PP], the wh-phrase may not be extracted via [Spec, PP] to get around the HC. 4 So movement out of the PP in (26) should violate the HC, contrary to facts.

subsection.heading: 3 A syntactic reanalysis account for P-stranding
subsection.p: Hornstein and Weinberg (1981: 60–61) propose a Case-theoretic approach to P-stranding. Specifically, they claim that languages may resort to a syntactic rule of reanalysis applying to VP, and that there is a universal filter against traces with oblique Case:

(27)
a. Syntactic rule of Reanalysis:
V → V* (where V c-commands all elements in V*)
b. Oblique Case Filter:

They further assume a Case-marking rule that marks an NP with a [+oblique] Case if it is governed by P (cf. Chomsky 1980a; Rouveret and Vergnaud 1980); crucially, the Case-marking rule must apply after reanalysis. Along these lines, the syntactic rule of reanalysis would apply to the VP in (15a) to produce a complex verb like that in (28b) or (28c):

(28)
a. John [VP [V talked [PP to Harry] [PP about Fred]]].
b. John [VP [V talked to] Harry [PP about Fred]].
c. John [VP [V talked to Harry about] Fred].

The (apparent) object of the preposition (to or about) is in fact an object of the reanalyzed verb, and the wh-phrase object of these reanalyzed verbs may now be extracted since it is no longer governed and Case-marked with a [+oblique] Case by P after reanalysis:

(29)
a. Whoi did John [VP [V talk to] ti [PP about Fred]]?
b. Whoi did John [VP [V talk to Harry about] ti ]?

The reanalysis rule in (27) has certain intuitive appeal since the structural relation between the trace of the extracted wh-phrase and the V+P complex predicate is exactly like that between the trace of the extracted object and a simple verb. The reanalysis account of P-stranding correctly predicts that P may not be stranded if it heads a PP that is not part of a VP, since the syntactic rule of reanalysis applies only to elements attaching to VP. Thus, P-heads of sentential PPs, PPs in COMP, or extraposed PPs cannot be stranded, these PPs not being (locally) c-commanded by V (Postal 1972: 213, 216): 5

(30)
a. *What timei did John arrive [PP at ti ]?
b. What conclusioni did John arrive [PP at ti ]?

(31)
a. *Who(m)j do you believe Fred thinks [PP to tj ]i Joan talked ti ?
b. *Who(m)j do you believe [PP to tj ]i Fred thinks Joan talked ti ?

(32)
a. Whoi did John [V talk to ti ] about Harry yesterday?
b. ??Whoj did John talk ti about Harry [PP to tj ]i yesterday?

The grammatical contrast in (33) also follows since the reanalysis rule in (27) presumably fails to apply to V and P when the two are separated by an adverbial, the PP plausibly appearing in an adjunct position and the head P no longer being c-commanded by V: 6

(33)
a. They stepped repeatedly on the carpet.
b. *The carpet was stepped repeatedly on.

An implication of the reanalysis rule in (27a) is that the elements and the V with which they are reanalyzed must be adjacent (Hornstein and Weinberg 1981: 67), so that the rule can apply to cases like (25a), repeated in (34a), where P and V are adjacent, turning it into the structure in (34b):

(34)
a. Je zei dat hij [VP [PP
de boom in] geklommen] is. Dutch
you said that he
the tree in climbed is
‘You said that he climbed into that tree.’
b. Je zei dat hij [VP [DP de boom] [V in geklommen]] is.
c. Welke boomk
zei je dat hij [VP tk [V
in geklommen]] is?
which tree say you that he
in climbed is
‘Which tree did you say that he climbed into?’
A wh-phrase object of the reanalyzed verb can now extract, as in (34c). The same account would work in German as well:

(35)
a. . . . weil man nie [VP [PP
davon [V
hörte]]] German
because one never
it-of heard
‘. . . because one never heard of it.’
b. . . . weil man nie [VP da [V von hörte]]
c. . . . weil man dai nie [VP ti [V von hörte]]

There are several empirical and conceptual problems with the reanalysis account of P-stranding. Empirically, if extraction of the sort in (28) is the result of P being reanalyzed with V so that the object of P would become the object of the reanalyzed V+P, then we should expect P and V to behave as a syntactic unit. The expectation is not borne out, however:

(36)
a. *[V
in klom]i
Jan de boom niet ti ? Dutch
in climbed Jan the tree not
‘Did Jan not climb into the tree?’
b. *[V
von hörte]i
man da nie ti ? German
of heard one it not
‘Did one never hear of it?’

In addition, in cases like those in (37) where the P is clearly not adjacent to V and cannot be reanalyzed with it, the reanalysis account of P-stranding would lead us to expect that the object of P may not be extracted: 7

(37)
a. Woi
hörte man nie [PP ti
von]? German
what heard one never
of
‘What did one never hear of?’
b. Welke boomi
klom Jan [PP ti
in]? Dutch
which tree climbed Jan
in
‘Which tree did Jan climb into?’
The fact that it may be extracted shows that there is an empirical problem with this account, the same problem we saw in (26).

Conceptually, insofar as the examples in (30–32) can be excluded on independent grounds, the ungrammaticality of these examples may turn out to have no bearing on the filter ruling out traces marked with oblique Case. The sentential PP in (30), the preposed PP in (31) (it is unclear, however, whether these are in COMP, i.e., [Spec, CP]) and the extraposed PP in (32) are evidently in adjoined positions, and extraction out of adjuncts is independently excluded by Huang's (1982a) Condition on Extraction Domain (CED). Therefore, to the extent that the examples in (38) do not bear on reanalysis as they obviously do not involve P-stranding, there is no reason to suppose that those in (30–32) are not ruled out by the CED, but by the filter in (27b):

(38)
a. *Whati did John read the newspaper [before Bill wrote ti ]?
b. *Which booki did Fred met the man [who bought ti ].
c. *About who(m)j did John claim (that) [books tj ]i many people will buy ti ?
We can conclude that the ungrammaticality of the examples in (30–32) is no evidence for the filter in (27).

The reanalysis-account of P-stranding is also inadequate from a cross-linguistic point of view. As Hornstein and Weinberg (1981: 68) note, one must assume that languages like Romance, which do not allow P-stranding at all, have no syntactic rule of reanalysis. But if no other property is brought to bear on the lack of P-stranding, then the assumption is simply a conceptually unsatisfying stipulation.

subsection.heading: 4 Government-theoretic accounts of P-stranding
subsection.p: We will now look at two government-theoretic accounts of P-stranding. One is related to the government and Case property of a lexical head, and the other to the direction of government.

subsection.heading: 4.1 The government and Case property of lexical heads
subsection.p: Kayne (1984a: 114ff) accepts the existence of a reanalysis rule in English, but what is involved is not so much reanalysis qua constituent as suggested by Hornstein and Weinberg (1981) as reanalysis in terms of government (Rouveret and Vergnaud 1980). In fact, French causatives (Rouveret and Vergnaud 1980) and complex predicates involving Ns and Vs (Pollock 1979) are two cases of reanalysis:

(39)
a. faire lire ‘to cause to read’, laisser partir ‘to let go’
b. mettre fin à ‘to put an end to’

Kayne proposes a constraint on reanalysis to the effect that elements under-going the reanalysis rule must be governed in the same way. He argues that Vs and Ps govern in the same way in English in assigning structural case, whereas in French Ps do not govern and assign Case structurally like Vs. Consequently, Vs and Ps may be reanalyzed in English, but not in French.

Kayne (1984a) points out three differences between English and French, claiming that they bear on government. First, the English prepositional complementizer (P-complementizer) for allows an overt subject in the embedded clause, but the French P-complementizer de (or à) does not:

(40)
a. It would be a pity for something to happen to him.
b. For there to be riot would be catastrophic.

(41)
a. *Ce serait dommage de quelque chose lui arriver. French
it would be pity to some thing to him arrive
‘It would be a pity for something to happen to him.’
b. *D’il y avoir une émeute serait catastrophal.
to-it there have a riot would be catastrophic
‘For there to be a riot would be catastrophic.’
Second, French de permits a phonetically empty pronominal in the embedded [Spec, IP] position, while English for does not:

(42)
a. Ce serait dommage de PRO partir maintenant. French
it would be pity to leave now
‘It would be a pity to leave now.’
b. *Ce serait dommage de Jean partir maintenant.
it would be pity to John leave now
‘It would be a pity for John to leave now.’

(43)
a. It would be a pity for John to leave now.
b. *It would be a pity for PRO to leave now.

Third, English generally allows a lexical subject in an infinitival complement to Exceptional Case-marking (ECM) verbs, but French permits it only to the extent that the lexical subject undergoes wh-movement:

(44)
a. I believe John to be the most intelligent of all.
b. John considers there to be a problem.

(45)
a. *Je crois Jean être le plus intelligent de tous. French
I believe John be the most intelligent of all
‘I believe John to be the most intelligent of all.’
b. Quel garçon crois-tu être le plus intelligent de tous?
which boy believe-you be the most intelligent of all
‘Which boy do you believe to be the most intelligent of all?’

Kayne claims that these three differences between English and French would have a unified account if in French Vs govern structurally, but Ps govern NP only in the sense of subcategorization, while in English both Vs and Ps govern structurally. That is, whereas V in the position X may govern P in both configurations in (46), but P, unlike V, does not necessarily do so, depending on the language:
Specifically, P governs P from the position X in the configuration in (46b) in English, but not in French.

The assumption that French Ps do not govern structurally explains why French de allows a phonetically null pronominal PRO in the YP position in (46b) but not a lexical one, the position not being governed (cf. the PRO theorem, Chomsky 1981). Kayne further suggests that ECM-complements are headed by a phonetically empty P-complementizer Φ in the C position, which assigns Case to the embedded subject position by transmitting the Case it receives from V:

row.entry: I believe [CP [Φ [IP John [to be the most intelligent of all]]]].
*Je crois [CP [Φ [IP Jean [être le plus intelligent de tous]]]].

subsection.p: The grammatical contrast in (47) is then due to the different government property of the P-complementizer in the two languages. In English, it governs the embedded subject position and hence may assign Case to the embedded subject. In French it does not govern the embedded subject position, and hence cannot assign Case to it. An overt argument in the embedded subject position of an ECM-complement would then fail to be assigned Case, violating the Case Filter. Although the facts in (40–42) clearly indicate that English and French P-complementizers have different properties, the difference concerns only P-complementizers, not Ps in general. For Ps in PPs, French is pretty much the same as English; French Ps in PPs assign or check Case of their objects, and hence govern them, just like their English counterparts:

(48)
a. J’ai voté [PP
pour Jean].
I-have voted for John
‘I voted for Jean.’
b. J’ai parlé [PP
avec Jean].
I-have talked with John
‘I talked with John.’
c. J’ai [VP
vu Jean].
I-have seen John
‘I saw John.’

At least for Ps in PPs, then, they assign or check Case of their objects the same way as Vs. Now, if Case-assignment or checking requires government, a standard assumption in the framework at the time, and Ps govern the same way as Vs, contrary to Kayne's claim, then we should expect that V and P in (49a) and (49b) may be reanalyzed as one complex verb, and that the object of P may be extracted; but the fact is that it may not:

(49)
a. *Quel candidati
as-tu voté [PP
pour ti ]?
which candidate have-you voted for
‘Which candidate did you vote for?’
b. *Quii
as-tu parlé [PP
avec ti ]?
who have-you talked with
‘Who did you talk with?’
c. Quii
as-tu [VP
vu ti ]?
who have-you seen
‘Who did you see?’

It thus seems that the difference between English and French P-complementizers does not tell us much about the government property of Ps in general, and much less so whether P-stranding is related to government.

Kayne's government-theoretic account for the grammatical contrast in (45) is not without problems. If V may govern across one clausal boundary, but P may not, then a question arises as to how the trace of the embedded subject in (45b) would be (properly) governed when it is extracted, given the Empty Category Principle (Chomsky 1981):

(50)
Quel garçoni
crois-tu [CP ti [Φ [IP ti
[être le plus intelligent de tous]]]]?
which boy believe-you be the most intelligent of all
‘Which boy do you believe to be the most intelligent?’

Although some alternative explanation for the contrast in (45) may be provided for, 8 it seems clear that there is no good reason to suppose that the empty complementizer does not govern the embedded subject position.

From the cross-linguistic perspective, Kayne's government account of P-stranding would not work for the limited cases of P-stranding in German and Dutch. The examples in (51) are a minimal pair, differing only with respect to whether the object of the P is an R-pronoun or not:

(51)
a. Ik had eri
niet [PP ti
op] gerekend. Dutch
I had it not on counted
‘I had not counted on it.’
b. *Ik had hemi
niet [PP
op ti ] gerekend.
I had him not on counted
‘I had not counted on him.’

There is no reason to think that the P op ‘on’ has different government properties in (51), as both the R- and non-R pronoun objects are assigned or check the Case of P. In fact, Kayne (1984a: 116) noted that P-stranding in these languages might not involve reanalysis, but did not elaborate on why the distinction between R- and non-R pronoun bears on P-stranding. Thus, to the extent that the grammatical difference in (51) is left unaccounted for, the empirical coverage of the reanalysis account based on government seems to be confined to English and Romance.

subsection.heading: 4.2 Directionality of government and P-stranding
subsection.p: Bennis and Hoekstra (1984) suggest a government-theoretic account of P-stranding, crucially without reanalysis. Essentially following Kayne (1984a), they posit the gap condition in (52) for the relation between a gap and its antecedent (Bennis and Hoekstra 1984: 34):

(52)
Gap Condition:
A gap Z in a tree P is linked to its antecedent by a connected subtree of P which constitues a g-projection.
XP is a g-projection of the structural governor W of Z iff the head of XP c-governs Z or a g-projection of W.
X c(anonically)-governs Y iff X precedes Y in a VO language and follows Y in an OV language.

Koster's (1987) account is also along these lines, except the link between the gap and the antecedent is constrained by government harmony, requiring that the structural governors in the link between the antecedent and the gap govern in the same direction, similar to Kayne's suggestion that government in the same way is required for reanalysis.

With the Gap Condition in (52), the grammatical contrast in (51) is accounted for as follows. In the structure in (53a) for the example in (51a), the trace is linked to its antecedent by a connected subtree, the VP, which constitutes a g-projection of the structural governor op ‘on’ of the trace ti :

(53)
a. Ik had [VP eri [VP niet [VP [PP ti op] gerekend]]]]
‘I had not counted on it.’
b. *Ik had [VP hemi [VP niet [VP [PP op ti ] gerekend]]]
‘I had not counted on him.’

The head gerekend of the VP c-governs the PP projection of op, and the PP in turn is a g-projection of the structural governor op of the trace which is c-governed by op. 9 By contrast, the gap in (53b) is not linked to its antecedent by a connected g-projection, the P op not c-governing the gap.

A major problem with these government-theoretic accounts is that they give no genuine explanation as to why P-stranding is possible in English and Scandinavian languages, while it is impossible in Romance, even though they are all VO languages, a problem also acknowledged in Bayer's (1996: 93, n. 7) account of P-stranding based on the canonical direction of government. In the English examples in (1a) and (2a), repeated in (54), the gap is linked to its antecedent by a connected g-projection:

(54)
a. Which booki have they [VP talked [PP about ti ]]?
b. That booki has been [VP talked [PP about ti ]].
In the French counterparts of the examples in (54), given in (55), the gap is also linked to its antecedent by a connected g-projection:

(55)
a. *Quel livrei
as-tu [VP
parlé [PP
de ti ]]? French
which book have-you talked about
‘Which book have you talked about?’
b. *Ce livrei
a été [VP
parlé [PP
de ti ]]?
this book have been talked about
‘This book has been talked about.’

But the problem remains as so why there should be a sharp grammatical difference between (54) and (55) with respect to P-stranding. Bennis and Hoekstra (1984: 35, 41) note this problem, but simply say that whether or not a specific category is a structural governor appears to some extent to be a language particular matter. This is at best a restatement of the facts.

There is also a conceptual problem with the formulation of canonical government in (52). It is not defined in terms of government, so a category may in principle be a canonical governor without being a governor, or vice versa. This problem is a technical one, and can easily be rectified with no serious consequences for the Gap Condition. A more significant conceptual problem is the notion of canonical government. To the extent that it has no bearing on other facts, it remains to be seen whether the notion of canonical government is warranted.

subsection.heading: 5 P-stranding and syntactic D-to-P-incorporation
subsection.p: It is a noticeable fact about Romance and German that P sometimes coalesces with the following D into a suppletive form, as illustrated in (56–58): 10

(56)
a. Jean a parlé du sujet le plus difficile. French
has talked about-the subject the most difficult
‘John talked about the most difficult subject.’
b. Suppletive forms:
au=à le, aux=à les, ‘to the’; auquel=à lequel, auxquels=à lesquels ‘to the which’
du=de le, des=de les ‘of the’; duquel=de lequel, desquels=de lesquels ‘of the which’

Intuitively, a suppletive form may be taken to indicate that two elements the suppletive form represents are no longer separable. Moreover, as P-stranding is the result of moving the DP object of the P, the lack of P-stranding may be considered to be a consequence of P not being separable from the following D. What we need is some theoretical rationale for this intuition. But the conceptual approach should be clear. Given the independent property of having suppletive forms for the sequence P+D that Romance and Germanic share, it is natural to bring it to bear on the lack of P-stranding in these languages.

subsection.heading: 5.1 A syntax–morphology-interface condition on P-stranding
subsection.p: Suppose the mapping between syntax and morphology is subject to the syntax–morphology-interface condition in (59) (cf. Law 1998; Van Riemsdijk 1998b):

(59)
Syntactic constraint on suppletion:
Elements that undergo suppletive rules must form a syntactic unit X0.

From this perspective, then, the suppletion facts in (56–58) can be taken to be evidence that D incorporates into P in overt syntax, resulting in the configuration in (60), so that the P+D as a syntactic unit X0 may undergo a suppletive rule:

It is now easy to see why D+NP may not be extracted in the structure in (60). Here, the incorporated D and the following NP (or DP) do not form a syntactic constituent. Consequently, P cannot be stranded by moving D+NP (or D+DP) (cf. Schwartz 1972 on constraints against moving non-constituents).

Notice that the condition in (59) does not require that elements forming a syntactic X0 necessarily undergo suppletion. Thus, a verb with agreement and tense morphologies need not have suppletive forms, even though they sometimes do. 11 So there is no requirement that a suppletive form exist whenever D incorporates into P. Unless there is evidence to the contrary (cf. section 6), the null hypothesis is that all Ds incorporate into Ps in Romance and Germanic except English. 12

Further facts about P-complementizers in Romance support the claim that suppletion rules may apply only to elements forming a syntactic X0. As shown in (61), the French P-complementizers de and à (Huot 1977) do not coalesce with the following clitic pronoun le (homophonous with the determiner le), in contrast with the Ps in PPs:

(61)
a. Je lui ai demandé [de le/*du lire]. French
I him have asked to it/to-it read
‘I asked him to read it.’
b. Nous sommes prêts [à le/*au faire].
we are ready to it/to-it do
‘We are ready to do it.’

From the perspective of the constraint in (59), the impossible suppletions in (61) have a very simple explanation: the object pronominal clitics and the P-complementizers do not form an X0. The positioning of the clitics shows that this is correct.
In finite clauses, an object pronominal clitic occurs between the subject and the finite verb, i.e., below [Spec, IP]:

(62)
a. Jean le lit French
John it read
‘John is reading it.’
b. *le Jean lit.
c. [IP Jean [le lit]].

Hence, there is little reason to think that in infinitivals the object pronominal clitic appears in a position higher than [Spec, IP]. If this is correct, then the object clitic, occurring below [Spec, IP], would not be in a position to incorporate into the P-complementizer to form a syntactic X0 with it: 13

(63)
a. . . . [CP de [IP [le lire . . .
b. . . . [CP à [IP [le faire . . .
So the suppletive forms du and au cannot arise since they do not meet the required syntactic condition for suppletion in (59).

If P-stranding correlates with (the lack of) D-to-P incorporation, then we should expect that P may be stranded when D does not incorporate into P, regardless of whether the complement of P is extracted under A-bar-movement, as we have been discussing so far, or under A-movement (prepositional passive, henceforth P-passive). As we will see, the prediction is largely borne out, subject to independent constraints on A-movement.

subsection.heading: 5.2 Lack of P-stranding in Romance
subsection.p: If noun phrases are projections of Ds, then wh-items like que ‘what’ qui ‘who’ and quel ‘which’ in French or che ‘what’ cui ‘who’ and qual ‘which’ in Italian are plausibly Ds. French que ‘what’ and qui ‘who’ as well as Itatian che ‘what’ cui ‘who’ may appear by themselves:

(64)
a. Que vois-tu? French
what see-you
‘What do you see?’
b. Qui vient?
who come
‘Who is coming?’

(65)
a. Che vedi? Italian
what see.2sg
‘What do you see?’
b. Chi viene?
who come
‘Who is coming?’

Given that noun phrases are projections of Ds, the sole appearance of que ‘what’, qui ‘who’, che ‘what’, and cui ‘who’ implies that they must be Ds. Furthermore, as the determiner is almost always obligatory in noun phrases in Romance, the fact that a determiner does not appear (in fact, it may not) when French quel ‘which’ or Italian qual ‘which’ appears shows that quel and qual are probably Ds:

(66)
a. Quel livre as-tu lu? French
which book have-you read
‘Which book did you read?’
b. Quale piazza visitiamo? Italian
which square visit.1pl
‘Which square are we visiting?’
French quel and Italian qual also inflect for number, just like the determiners, showing further that they are probably of the same category: 14

(67)
a. Quels/*quel enfants as-tu vu? French
which.pl/*which.sg
children have-you seen
‘Which children did you see?’
b. Quali/*quale monumenti visitiamo? Italian
which.pl/*which.sg
monuments visit.1pl
‘Which momuments are we visiting?’

If other Ds incorporate into Ps as the suppletion facts in (56–57) show, then there is no reason why the same does not hold of que, qui, quel, che, cui, or qual ‘which’ when they are complements to a P.
We can now understand why P-stranding under A-bar-movement of the sort in (68) is impossible:

(68)
a. *Quel sujeti
as-tu parlé de ti ? French
which subject have-you talked about
‘Which subject did you talk about?’
b. . . . [PP [[de+queli ] [DP ti [NP sujet]]]]
c. Qui a parlé duquel sujet?
who have talked about-the subject
‘Who talked about which subject?’
d. Duquel sujeti
as-tu parlé
about-which subject have-you talked
‘About which subject did you talk?’

In the structure in (68b), the head D quel incorporates into the P de, most evident in (68c) and (68d) with the suppletive form duquel, and hence can no longer A-bar-move with its NP-complement, the two no longer forming a syntactic constituent. The same argument applies to cases of A-movement. As is well known, Romance is unlike English in not having P-passive, as shown in (69):

(69)
a. *Le sujet a été parlé de. French
the subject have been talked about
‘The subject was talked about.’
b. . . . [PP [[de+lei ] [DP ti [NP sujet]]]]
c. Ils ont parlé du sujet.
they have talked about-the subject
‘They talked about the subject.’

The ungrammaticality of the example in (69a) has exactly the same explanation. The determiner le incorporates into the P de, most evident in (69c), and hence cannot move with P as a syntactic unit to derive the example in (69a), the two no longer forming a syntactic constituent. It thus seems that relating D-to-P incorporation, as evidenced independently in the suppletive forms, we can explain in a principled way why Romance languages generally do not allow P-stranding.

subsection.heading: 5.3 P-stranding under A-bar-movement in German and Dutch
subsection.p: For German and Dutch, the lack of P-stranding under A-bar-movement has the same account as that for Romance. Like French que and qui and Italian che and chi, German wer and was ‘what’ and Dutch wie and wat may occur by themselves. On the assumption that noun phrases are headed by Ds, it must be the case that wer and was in German and wie and wat in Dutch in wh-phrases containing them as the sole constituent are of the category D (the example in (71a) sounds more natural with er ‘there’ in the end, a point irrelevant here):

(70)
a. Wer kommt? German
who comes
‘Who is coming?’
b. Was hast du gekauft?
what have you bought
‘What did you buy?’

(71)
a. Wie komt? Dutch
who comes
‘Who is coming?’
b. Wat heb je gekocht?
what have you bought
‘What did you buy?’
Moreover, as German welche ‘which’ and Dutch welke ‘which’ inflect for gender, number, and, in German, for Case as well (just like the determiner), they are plausibly of the category D (cf. n. 14):

(72)
a. Ich habe dem/*den Mann geholfen. German
I have the.dat/the.acc
man helped
‘I helped the man.’
b. Welchem/*welchen Mann hast du geholfen?
which.dat/which.acc
man have you helped
‘Which man have you helped?’

(73)
a. Welk/*welke boek heb je gelezen Dutch
which book have you read
‘Which book did you read?’
b. Welke/*welk film heb je gezien?
which film have you seen
‘Which film did you see?’

So if other Ds incorporate into P as the suppletion facts in (57) show, then there is no reason why the same does not apply to wer, was, welche or wie wat, and welke when they are complements to a P. We can now understand why P may not be stranded under A-bar-movement. In the example in (74a), the D welchem incorporates into the P, as shown in the structure in (74b); it therefore cannot move with its NP complement, since the two do not form a syntactic constituent:

(74)
a. *Welchem Kerl hast du mit gerechnet? German
which guy have you with counted
‘Which guy have you counted on?’
b. . . . [PP [[mit+welchemi ] [DP [ti Kerl]]]] . . .
What we need to explain is why P-stranding, albeit limited, is sometimes possible with R-pronouns, as shown in the example in (6), repeated in (75): 15

(75)
a. Woi /*Wasi
redest du von ti ? German
what talk you.nom
from
‘What are you talking about?’
b. Waari /*Wati
heb je op ti
gerekend? Dutch
what have you on
counted
‘What have you counted on?’
The obvious difference between wo and was and between waar and wat is that wo or waar must appear to the left of the P taking it as argument, while was and wat must occur to its right.

If we take R-pronouns appearing to the left of P to be in [Spec, PP] (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1978a and Corver 1990), from where it cannot incorporate into P (cf. Travis's 1984 Head Movement Constraint), it then follows immediately that they may move out of PP, stranding P: 16

(76)
a. Woi
hast du [PP ti
[mit]] gerechnet? German
what have you
with counted
‘What have you counted on?’
b. Waari
heb je [PP ti
[op]] gerekend? Dutch
what have you
on counted
‘What have you counted on?’

Examples like those in (77) independently show that Dutch R-pronouns are not incorporated into P. Here, an R-pronoun is separated by an adverbial from the P taking it as argument (cf. Van Riemsdijk 1978a: 87) as in (77a), 17 and it may move together with both the adverb and the P as in (77b), or by itself, stranding P, as in (77c) and (77d): 18

(77)
a. Vlak er achter vs. er vlak achter. Dutch
right it after
‘right after it’
b. [PP
er vlak achter]i
geloof ik dat Jan toen ti
stond.
it right after believe I that
then stood
‘I believe that Jan then stood right behind it.’
c. Ik geloof dat Jan eri toen [PP ti vlak achter] stond.
d. Waari
denk je dat Jan [PP ti
vlak achter] stond?
where think you that Jan
right after stood
‘Where do you think that Jan stood right behind?’
Exactly the same account can be given to cases like (26), repeated in (78), where P is stranded as a result of extracting a non-R-pronoun:

(78)
a. Welke boomk
klom Jan [PP tk
in]? Dutch
which tree climbed Jan
into
‘Which tree did Jan climb into?’
b. Ik geloof dat Jan de boomk
gisteren [PP tk
in] ti
is geklommeni .
I think that Jan the tree yesterday
in is climbed
‘I think that Jan climbed into the tree yesterday.’
c. Welke boomk
zei je dat hij [PP tk
in] ti
is geklommeni ?
which tree say you that he
in is climbed
‘Which tree did you say that he climbed into?’
Since the D head of the DP complement of the P in ‘in’ does not incorporate into P, as evidenced independently in (79) where it clearly is in [Spec, PP]:

(79)
a. Hij klom [PP
de boom in]. Dutch
he climbed
the tree in
‘He climbed into the tree.’
b. Wie klom [PP
welke boom in]?
who climbed
which tree in
‘Who climbed into which tree?’

The DP complement of P can then be extracted from [Spec, PP], stranding P. The lack of P-stranding under A-bar-movement in German and Dutch thus has exactly the same account as that for Romance, P being no longer separable from D as a result of D incorporating into P. In the few cases where P-stranding is possible, it is due to the head D of the DP complement of P not incorporating into P.

subsection.heading: 5.4 P-stranding under A-movement in Germanic
subsection.p: If the lack of P-stranding correlates with D-to-P incorporation, then we would expect P-stranding to be possible precisely when D does not incorporate into P. We saw in the last section that the expectation is largely borne out under A-bar-movement. The question that naturally arises is whether we can reasonably expect that P-stranding under A-movement is also possible when D does not incorporate into P. The null hypothesis is that it should be, but there is a complication; as we will see presently, some general conditions may exclude A-movement. Thus, cases where P may not be stranded under A-movement may turn out to fall under the same conditions.

As we discussed in section 5.2, when D incorporates into P, the object of the P may not extract, stranding P. The ungrammaticality of the example in (80b) is thus just as expected, if D incorporates into P as in (80c):

(80)
a. Es wurde völlig mit dem Kerl gerechnet. German
it became fully with the guy counted
‘The guy have been fully counted on.’
b *Dem Kerli
wurde völlig mit ti
gerechnet.
the.dat guy became fully with counted
‘The guy has been fully counted on.’
c. . . . [PP [[in+demi ] [DP ti Kerl]]]
As R-pronouns do not incorporate into P, they may move out of PP and thereby strand P. In this light, the facts in (81) are unsurprising:

(81)
a. Es wurde völlig [PP
da [mit]] gerechnet. German
it became fully it on counted
‘It has been fully counted on.’
b. Es wurde dai völlig [PP ti [mit]] gerechnet.
c. Dai wurde völlig [PP ti [mit]] gerechnet.

The examples in (81) evidently do not involve movement of a wh-phrase, typical of A-bar-movement. One might thus be lead to suppose that movement of the sort in (80b) and (81b) are instances of A-movement. However, for virtually all analyses of verb-second root clauses, a non-subject appearing before the verb in second position is in [Spec, CP], an A-bar position on standard assumptions (Travis 1984; Haider and Prinzhorn 1986). If this is correct there might not be any structure resulting from P-stranding under A-movement in Germanic languages other than English at all. As it turns out, English systematically differs from other Germanic languages with respect to Case and agreement in a class of constructions including the impersonal passive construction with an overt expletive. As we will see presently, in English, when the participle carries passive morphology, the logical object, which otherwise receives accusative case, generally appears in subject position with nominative Case and agrees with the finite verb in number and person. This is not necessarily so in other Germanic languages. Since P-stranding under A-movement involves passive, we may naturally wonder whether the difference between English and other Germanic languages with respect to Case and agreement in passive bears on P-passive, the result of stranding P under A-movement.

As is familiar since Aoun (1979) and Chomsky (1981), the passive morpheme on the passive participle (mostly -ed or -en in English) is commonly taken to absorb accusative Case for the object, which then has to move to a Case position, e.g., the subject position of a finite verb, where it may be assigned (or check) nominative Case:

(82)
a. John and Maryi were/*was killed ti .
b. *It/there were/was killed John and Mary.

If the object of a verb with passive morphology does not move, as in (82b), then the structure would be excluded by the Case Filter (Rouveret and Vergnaud 1980), barring overt noun phrases without Case. A distinct feature of the passive construction is that the finite verb agrees in number with the (logical) object in subject position, as shown in the contrast in (82a). The same agreement fact holds of German passives as well: 19

(83)
. . . , dass Hans und Maria getötet wurden/*wurde. German
that Hans and Maria killed became.pl/*became.sg
‘. . . , that Hans and Maria were killed.’

However, there is a class of examples in which the apparent subject systematically does not agree with the finite verb. With verbs assigning non-accusative Case to the object, the finite verb in the passive shows no agreement with the (logical) object appearing in a preverbal position, as illustrated by the examples in (84) for Icelandic (Levin and Simpson 1981) and German in (85):

(84)
a. þeim var hjálpað. Icelandic
them.dat
was helped
‘They were helped.’
b. Mig þyrstir.
me.acc
thirsts
‘I am thirsty.’

(85)
a. Ihnen wurde/*wurden geholfen. German
them.dat
became.sg/became.pl
helped
‘They have been helped.’
b. Mir ist kalt.
me.dat
is cold
‘I'm cold.’

Agreement with the finite verb in the example in (81) turns out to pattern like that in (86). The German pronoun da may have a plural antecedent (cf. einer davon ‘one of them’), and yet it may not agree with a finite verb, as shown in (86a). 20 In the Icelandic example in (86b), the (logical) object of a P assigning accusative Case appears before the finite verb, but it does not agree with it:

(86)
a. Dai
wurde/*wurden völlig [PP ti
mit] gerechnet. German
they became.sg/became.pl
fully with counted
‘They are counted on.’
b. Krakkanai
er/*eru oftast talað vel [PP
um ti ] Icelandic
the kids.acc
is/are usually spoken well of
‘The kids are usually well spoken of.’
With respect to agreement, then, English differs from other Germanic languages in that the (logical) object (of V or of P) agrees with the finite verb when it appears preverbally in passive:

(87)
a. The carpeti has/*have been stepped [PP on ti ].
b. The carpetsi have/*has been stepped [PP on ti ].
c. The carpeti has/*have been sold ti .
d. The carpetsi have/*has been sold ti .

We will later see the significance of the agreement facts, but for now let us see whether we should consider P-stranding of the sort in (84–85) on a par with P-stranding under A-bar-movement (cf. section 5.3).

Maling and Zaenen (1985) argue that Icelandic examples comparable to those in (84a) are not genuine P-passives but involve topicalization of the object of the P, i.e., wh-movement. They give the Icelandic examples in (88) as evidence that the fronted objects of Ps are not in subject position, since they retain the Case assigned to them in-situ: 21

(88)
a. þessa konai
er oftast talað vel [PP
um ti ]. Icelandic
that woman.acc
is usually spoken well of
‘The woman is usually spoken well of.’
b. þennan refi
hefur aldrei verið skotið [PP
á ti ].
that fox.acc
has never been shot at
‘That fox has never been shot at.’

Furthermore, the extracted objects of the stranded Ps exhibit no subject properties like undergoing raising, binding of a reflexive, and being subject to locality for topicalization. The dative object of a verb may appear preverbally in a complement of an ECM verb, but the object of a stranded P may not do so: 22

(89)
a. Ég tel honum hafa verið hjálpað í prófinu. Icelandic
I believe him.dat
to-have been helped in the-exam
‘I believe him to have been helped in the exam.’
b. *Ég tel Vigdísi vera oftast talað vel um.
I believe Vigdis to-be most-often spoken well of
‘I believe Vigdis to be most often well spoken of.’
The dative object of a verb appearing preverbally may bind a reflexive, but the object of a stranded P may not:

(90)
a. Honum var oft hjálpað af foreldrum sínum/*hans.
him.dat
was often helped by parents his[+refl]/*[−refl]
‘He was often helped by his parents.’
b. Hana er talað vel um í hennar eigin landu/í landi ?*sínu.
she.acc
is spoken well of in her own land/in land her[+refl]
‘She is well spoken of in her own land.’

Many speakers allow topicalization in embedded að ‘that’-clauses but not in binding domains like indirect questions, comparatives, and relatives, i.e., syntactic islands. They crucially distinguish objects of verbs and objects of Ps:

(91)
a. Hann spurði, hvenær henni hefði verið hjálpað.
he.nom
asked when she.dat
had been helped
‘He asked when she had been helped.’
b. *Hann spurði, hvort Vigdísi væri talað vel um.
he.nom
asked whether Vigdis was spoken well of
‘He asked whether Vigdis was well spoken of.’

Maling and Zaenen thus conclude that P-stranding is not a unified phenomenon, and suggest that P-passive is possible only when there is some independent lexical process reanalyzing V and P, which turns the object of P into the direct object of the reanalyzed V+P. The difference between English and Icelandic with respect to P-passive is that English has a rule of lexical reanalysis but Icelandic does not.

They argue that prenominal modifiers of the sort in (92) constitute independent evidence for a reanalysis rule in English, and the lack thereof in Icelandic as in (93) and (94) shows that V cannot be reanalyzed with P, even though the language allows prenominal modifiers that are related to verbs:

(92)
a. a much talked about subject
b. an often alluded to problem
c. a well spoken of young lady

(93)
a. **Þettaer [vel töluð um] kona. Icelandic
‘This is a well spoken of woman.’
b. *Þettaer [vel umtöluð] kona.

(94)
a. Nýfallinn snjór.
‘new snow’
b. Sokkna skipið.
‘the sunken ship’
c. Mikið lesin bók.
‘a much read book’

The grammatical contrasts in (92–94), and, by the same token, those in (89–91) as well, certainly call for an explanation, but it is not quite clear whether they are due to the lack of a lexical rule reanalyzing V and P in Icelandic.
In fact, if P-stranding is possible only if P is reanalyzed with V, 23 then it must be that P is reanalyzed with V in cases like (95) (Maling and Zaenen 1985: 199):

(95)
Hann spurði hvern ég hefði talað við. Icelandic
he asked whom I had talked to
‘He asked whom I had talked to.’

We can surely distinguish the example in (95), a result of A-bar-movement, from those in (89b) and (91b), results of A-movement, and argue as Maling and Zaenen do that the grammatical examples in (86b), (88), and (90b) are the results of A-bar-movement. What this amounts to is that P-stranding under A-movement, i.e., P-passive, requires lexical reanalysis of V and P, but P-stranding under A-bar-movement does not. Maling and Zaenen (1985: 205) attribute the requirement to the assumption that only arguments bearing the grammatical function OBJ may passivize (Zaenen and Maling 1983). Thus, unless it comes to bear the grammatical function OBJ, object of P cannot passivize, i.e., P may not be stranded under A-movement. The requirement does not hold of arguments undergoing A-bar-movement, since syntactic binding, i.e., wh-movement, is not restricted to arguments bearing the grammatical function OBJ.

There are three major problems with this account, however. First, there is little, if any, independent morphological evidence for P being reanalyzed with V. Morphologically, the participial suffix -ed occurs on V regardless of whether it is reanalyzed with P. If V is reanalyzed with P, we could reasonably expect the participial morphology to appear on the whole reanalyzed unit (e.g., [talk about]-ed). The fact that it does not shows that there is no morphological evidence for P being reanalyzed with V. Second, there is no independent motivation for assuming that object of P may bear the OBJ grammatical function. Third, the assumption that the process of lexical reanalysis may vary from language to language is at best a restatement of the cross-linguistic variations with respect to P-passive, if the process is not shown to be related to any other processes or principles of grammar.

Questions of this kind would cease to arise if there is in fact no condition on P-stranding specific to A-movement, and the more limited possibilities of P-stranding in structures without wh-movement are in fact related to independent properties. I would like to suggest that the possibility of stranding P under A-movement, as observed for English, is related to Case.

The standard assumption about agreement with a finite verb is that the verb is in I0 and the argument agreeing with it in [Spec, IP]. Along these lines, then, what the lack of agreement in (84–85) – examples without P-stranding – and in (86) – examples with P-stranding – suggests is that the preverbal argument in all these cases is not in [Spec, IP]. These examples are thus in sharp contrast with the English example in (87) where the preverbal argument appears in [Spec, IP] and agrees with the finite verb. There are two related questions that we need to address. First, why should it be that the preverbal argument in German and Icelandic is not in [Spec, IP]? Second, why should it be that the preverbal argument in English is in [Spec, IP]? These two questions lead to a third, more general, question: is there some other difference between English and other Germanic languages that bears on the anwers to the first two questions? Before considering these questions, let us note that these issues are quite independent of P-stranding; the same questions arise for the examples in (84–85) and (87c) where there is no P-stranding.

I would like to first discuss some facts related to the third, more general question, as the answers to the first two questions hinge on it. As it turns out, Germanic languages exhibit a sharp division with respect to the impersonal passive construction. All Germanic languages have it, except English (Vikner 1995: 209):

(96)
a. . . . daß pro
getanzt worden ist. German
that
danced became is
‘. . . that there was dancing.’
b. . . . að Það hefur verið dansað. Icelandic
that there has been danced
‘. . . that there was dancing.’
c. . . . at der er blevet danset. Danish
that it there became danced
‘. . . that there was dancing.’
d. *. . . that there/it has been danced.

The issue that arises for the grammatical contrast in (96) is why it is that English does not allow the impersonal passive construction, while all other Germanic languages do. Moreover, as the same sharp division, all Germanic languages on the one hand and English on the other, also holds of agreement with a preverbal argument (as discussed above), it seems quite natural to relate these two differences.

The (abstract) passive morpheme is commonly taken to absorb Case, which explains why the object of a passivized verb in English must move to a Case position. As for German, and by extension all other Germanic languages as well, the accusative Case for the object seems to be absorbed by the passive morpheme, as evidenced in (83), where the object is in subject position where it is assigned (or checks) nominative Case and agrees with the finite verb; but the passive morpheme in these other Germanic languages need not absorb any Case if the verb itself does not assign accusative Case to the object, as in (84) and (85). Suppose the Case-absorption property of the passive morpheme varies from language to language (Baker 1988a: 345ff., refining the Case-theoretic accounts of NP movement by Chomsky 1980a and Jaeggli 1982) in that it must absorb accusative Case in some languages, e.g., English, but it does not necessarily do so in some others, e.g., other Germanic languages. Specifically, the passive morpheme must absorb the accusative Case of the verb, if there is any, but particular languages may vary, as a parametric choice, as to whether the passive morpheme must absorb Case at all. It must in English, but need not do so in other Germanic languages, which explains why a verb assigning no accusative Case in these latter languages may bear passive morphology, but not in English.

The variations with respect to impersonal passives can now be related to the Case-absorption property of the passive morpheme. Thus, the example in (96d) is excluded since the passive morpheme in English must absorb Case, and there is none for it to absorb. In the examples in (87c) and (87d), the passive morpheme absorbs the accusative Case for the object, the object must therefore move to [Spec, IP] of a finite clause where nominative Case is assigned (or checked), and where it agrees with the finite verb. This answers the second question above. By contrast, the impersonal passive construction in (96a–c) is possible in Germanic languages other than English, since the passive morpheme in these languages need not absorb Case. The same account can be given to explain why in the examples in (84) in Icelandic and those in (85) in German the object retains its (non-accusative) Case. 24 As movement to [Spec, IP] is motivated by Case, the object with Case cannot move to [Spec, IP], explaining why the preverbal object in (84) and (85) does not agree with the finite verb. 25 This answers the first question above. Thus, the answer to the third, more general, question is that P-stranding under A-movement is related to the Case absorption property of the passive morphology, which manifests itself independently in the impersonal passive construction. If a language allows the impersonal construction, i.e., the passive morpheme need not absorb Case, then it will not allow an object with Case to move to [Spec, IP], there being no motivation for movement to [Spec, IP] for Case. P-stranding under A-movement in these languages is therefore only apparent, P being stranded not by A-movement of the object of P to [Spec, IP], a Case position, but by A-bar-movement to a non-Case position.

It bears pointing out that since there is very little, if at all, Case and agreement morphology in Swedish, Danish, and Norwegian. Therefore, there are no Case and agreement facts showing that the apparent P-passive is the the result of P-stranding under A-movement. Nevertheless, as these languages allow the impersonal passive construction, just like Icelandic, it thus seems reasonable to conclude that the passive morphology in these languages has the same Case absorption property as that in Icelandic, namely, it does not necessarily absorb Case. This is what makes the impersonal passive construction possible.

Now, if the English passive morpheme must absorb Case, then one might wonder how it absorbs Case in P-passive. In an example like that in (97a), the object the carpet of the P on plausibly receives Case from the P, and it is not obvious that the verb step has any Case feature:

(97)
a. They stepped on the carpet.
b. The carpeti has been stepped on ti
If this is correct, then how would the Case absorption property of the passive morpheme in English be satisfied in (97b), repeated from (87a)?

Law (1998) suggests that in P-passive the Case feature of P, which is otherwise checked by its argument, moves to the verb on which the passive morpheme appears (cf. Move-F, Chomsky 1995c: 261–271), so as to satisfy the Case absorption property of the passive morpheme. As a result, the object of the P must move to the subject position where it is assigned nominative Case, and agrees with the finite verb, just like other cases of passive. On this view, the example in (97b) would have the derivation as in (98):

If the Case feature of P must move to the participle, then we would expect it to be subject to constraints on movement. The expectation is borne out. In the example in (33b), repeated in (99a), an adverb intervenes between V and P, an indication that the PP is in an adjoined position:

P may not be stranded in (99a), since movement of the object of P to subject position as well as movement of the Case feature of P to the participle violate Huang's CED barring extraction out of adjuncts. It is noteworthy that the example in (99b) is slightly better than that in (99a), perhaps due to there being only one CED violation by the extraction of the wh-phrase. As the passive morpheme need not absorb Case in other Germanic languages, the Case feature of the P does not move to the verb that carries the passive morpheme, accounting for why the object of the P retains the Case assigned to it by the P, and why it cannot move to [Spec, IP], a Case position. 26 In this way, with the parametric choice of Case absorption, we can relate the retention of non-accusative Case and the impersonal passive construction with an overt expletive.

subsection.heading: 6 Some remaining problems and issues
subsection.p: The foregoing discussion emcompasses only facts in some standard varieties of Romance and Germanic languages. The question that naturally arises is whether the analysis can be extended to other varieties. I would like to discuss two cases that appear to raise some problems for the D-to-P incorporation analysis of P-stranding. The first case concerns the lack of D-to-P incorporation, as observed in cases where an adverb intervenes between P and D, in syntactic environments where movement is possible in principle. The second case concerns D-to-P incorporation, as manifested in the D+P suppletive forms, in syntactic environments where movement is generally impossible.

subsection.heading: 6.1 Lack of D-to-P incorporation
subsection.p: An apparent problem for the D-to-P-incorporation analysis of P-stranding is the impossible D-to-P incorporation in examples like (100–110) across all German dialects (Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 662–663):

(100)
a. von genau dem Gegenteil German
from exactly the.dat
opposite
‘from exactly the opposite’
b. *von dem genau Gegenteil
c. *vom genau Gegenteil

(101)
a. zu knapp der Hälfte
to nearly the half
‘to nearly half’
b. *zu der knapp Hälfte
c. *zur knapp Hälfte

Given that what follows P in (100–101) is a constituent, most clearly in verb-second main clauses, as shown in (102), the structures in (103a) and (103b) for (100a) and (100a), respectively, are perfectly reasonable:

(102)
a. [Genau das Gegenteil] hat er gesagt. German
exactly the.acc
opposite has he said
‘He said the exact opposite.’
b. [Knapp die Hälfte] sind meine Freunde.
nearly the.nom
half be my friends
‘Nearly half are my friends.’

(103)
a. von [genau dem Gegenteil]
b. zu [knapp der Hälfte]
Conceptually, then, the problem is why D in (103) may not incorporate into P as in (104), the structures for (100b) and (101b):

(104)
a. *von+demi [genau ti Gegenteil]
b. *zu+deri [knapp ti Hälfte]

The impossibility of P-to-D incorporation in (104) would follow immediately if the complement of P in these cases is in fact headed by genau ‘exactly’ or knapp ‘nearly’, as movement of D to P would violate Travis's HMC. But there seems to be little independent evidence for the complement of P in (103) being headed by genau or knapp. 27 Van Riemsdijk (1998b: 654–656) suggests that contraction of P and D is a result of head adjunction of D to P. As an instance of head movement, it is subject to the head-adjacency principle in (105) (Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 644–645), particularly relevant to the D-to-P incorporation is the condition on head adjunction:

(105)
The Head Adjacency Principle (HAP):
A transformational process that affects two head positions must be either Head Adjunction or Head Substitution.
Head Adjunction (HA):
Two phonetically identified heads are joined, yielding an adjunction structure, in which case the two heads must be strictly linearly adjacent at the moment of application of the rule.
Thus, the reason why D cannot move to P in (104) is that the two are not adjacent, there being an element intervening between them.

As it turns out, there seems to be some constraint in German barring stranding a left-modifier independently of P-stranding. As shown in (106), the R-pronoun da may move to [Spec, PP] or to a still higher position (cf. section 5.3). But it may not do so when a left-modifier like the adverbial genau ‘exactly’ is stranded as shown in (107) (the surface forms of the examples in (107b) and (107c) are good with the adverbial genau ‘exactly’ modifying the verb, i.e., it is not part of the PP headed by von ‘of’. Cf. the discussion of the examples in (109–110) below):

(106)
a. Hans hat [dai
[von ti ]] geredet.
Hans has it of talked
‘Hans talked of it.’
b. Dai hat Hans [ti [von ti ]] geredet.

(107)
a. Hans hat [von [genau diesem Thema]] geredet.
Hans has of exactly this topic talked
‘Hans talked of exactly this topic.’
b. *Hans hat [dai
[von [genau ti ]]] geredet.
Hans has it of exactly talked
c. *Dai hat Hans [ti [von [genau ti ]]] geredet.
Notice that there is nothing wrong, semantically, with the adverbial genau appearing with the R-pronoun da; the position of the adverbial is crucial:

(108)
a. Hans hat [genau [von [diesem Thema]]] geredet.
Hans has exactly of this topic talked
‘Hans talked of exactly this topic.’
b. Hans hat [genau [dai
[von ti ]]] geredet.
Hans has exactly it of talked
‘Hans talked of exactly it.’
c. Dai hat Hans [genau [ti [von ti ]]] geredet.
d. [genau [dai [von ti ]]] hat Hans geredet.

There is a complication with genau, however. As it may modify the verb, it is not straightforward to construct examples where it unambiguously modifies the verb or the DP that superfically follows it:

(109)
a. Hans hat genau erklärt, wer dafür zuständig ist.
Hans has exactly said, who it-for responsible is
‘Hans said exactly who is responsible for it.’
b. Die Details hat Hans nicht genau präzisiert.
the details has Hans not exactly specified
‘Hans did not exactly specify the details.’
That is, there are alternative structures for the same surface forms of the examples in (108a–c) where genau is not part of the PP, but modifies the verb:

(110)
a. Hans hat genau [von [diesem Thema]] geredet.
Hans has exactly of this topic talked
‘Hans talked exactly of this topic.’
b. Hans hat genau [dai
[von ti ]] geredet.
Hans has exactly it of talked
‘Hans talked exactly of it.’
c. Dai hat Hans genau [ti [von ti ]] geredet.
The modifier all ‘all’ is a better choice. Although it is like genau in that it is formally invariant and can precede a DP with different number, gender, and Case forms:

(111)
a. [All der gute Wein] steht auf dem Regal.
all the.sg.nom
good.sg.nom
wine.sg
stands on the shelf
‘All the good wine is on the shelf.’
b. Auf dem Regal stehen [all die guten Weine]
on the shelf stand all the.pl.nom
good.pl.nom
wine.pl
‘On the shelf is all the good wine.’
c. Hans hat [all den guten Wein] getrunken.
Hans has all the.sg.acc
good.sg.acc
wine.sg
drunk
‘Hans drank all the good wine.’
d. Hans hat [von all dem guten Wein] getrunken.
Hans has of all the.sg.dat
good.sg.dat
wine.sg
drunk
‘Hans drank from all the good wine.’
The modifier all differs from genau in not being able to modify a verb:

(112)
a. Hans hat all sein Geld verloren.
Hans has all his money lost
‘Hans lost all his money.’
b. *Hans hat all es verloren.
Hans has all it lost
‘Hans lost it all.’
c. Die Politiker haben alle/*all gelogen.
the politicians have all/all lied
‘The politicians have all lied.’
As shown in (113), the phrase left-modified by all may not be moved, leaving behind the modifier all:

(113)
a. *[ Die guten Weine] stehen [all ti ] auf dem Regal
the.pl.nom
good.pl.nom
wine.pl stand all on the shelf
‘On the shelf is all the good wine.’
b. *[ Den guten Wein]i
hat Hans [all ti ] getrunken.
the.sg.acc
good.sg.acc
wine.sg
has Hans all drunk
‘Hans drank all the good wine.’

Suppose for some reason a modifier may not be left-adjoined to a category whose head is phonetically empty. The examples in (113) would then be straightforwardly excluded. So are those in (104) and (114):
(114) *von+dem [all [ti guten Wein]]

In other words, the examples in (104) and (114) are ruled out not because P may not incorporate into D, but precisely because incorporation of D into P would give rise to structures in which a modifier is left-adjoined to a category whose head is devoid of phonetic content. This is exactly the reason why the examples in (113), which have no D-to-P incorporation, are excluded. What remains to be explained, however, is why D may have the option of not incorporating into P in (103).
There is some indication that there is a constraint that specifically bars stranding of a left-modifier. As shown in (115), a right-modifier may be stranded in German: 28

(115)
a. Hans hat [dai
[von ti
[was uns übrigens auch interessiert]]] geredet.
Hans has it of what us by the way also interested talked
‘Hans talked of it, which also interests us.’
b. [dai [von ti [was uns übrigens auch interessiert]]] hat Hans geredet.

Notice that the examples in (115) have a non-restrictive relative clause made explicit by the expression übrigens ‘by the way’; it is most plausibly adjoined to the DP-complement of P headed by the R-pronoun da. The examples in (113) show that the quantifier all is not part of the projection that moves leftward. The leftward movement of the R-pronoun in (115) essentially shows the same point. The bracketed phrase in (115) is thus structurally parallel to that in (113) in that the position of the relative clause in (115) is structurally comparable to that of the quantifier all in (113). The grammatical contrast between them shows that a left-modifier may not be stranded, while a right-modifier may. The un-grammaticality of the examples in (107b) and (107c), further instantiations of the structure in (104a), now follows since a left-modifier is stranded.

The HA clause of the HAP cannot explain why the examples in (107b) and (107c) are ungrammatical, since movement of the R-pronoun da is phrasal. The same also holds of the examples in (113). The constraint against stranding left-modifiers in German thus seems to have some empirical support, although it is conceptually unclear why there should be such a constraint.

The lack of D-to-P incorporation in Italian in cases like in (116) (Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 664) apparently raises a problem for the D-to-P analysis of P-stranding, as the explanation for the lack of P-to-D incorporation in German in cases like (100) and (101) cannot be carried over to Italian: 29

(116)
a. con tutta la famiglia. Italian
with whole.fem
the.fem
family.fem
‘with the whole family’
b. *con+lai [tutta [ti famiglia]] (*colla=con la)

As shown in (117), if the pronominal la ‘her/it.fem’ orignates in the position to the right of the quantifier tutta ‘all, whole’ and then moves to the verb (Kayne 1975), then the resulting structure would be comparable to that in (116b), which are just like the structures in (113) in German (the combination la ho is phonologically [lo], orthographically l’ho):

(117)
a. Lai
ho vista [tutta ti ] Italian
it.fem
have.1sg
seen all
‘I saw it all.’
b. Quale famiglia hai vista [tutta ti ]?
which family have.2sg seen all
‘Which family have you seen all?’

The fact that the structures in (117) are possible, but those in (113) and (116b) are not calls for an explanation. To approach the solution to the problem in (116b), we need to find out what the category of the quantifier tutta is, what relationship it bears with the following DP, and what the head of the DP tutta la famiglia ‘the whole family’ is. These questions are largely independent from one another. Let us first discuss the issue of the category of the quantifier tutta.
The examples in (118) show that the quantifier tutta is plausibly of the category determiner; it may appear by itself, without being followed by a DP (Schwarze 1988: 29):

(118)
a. Tutti sanno leggere. Italian
all can.3pl
read
‘All can read.’
b. Avete capito tutto?
have.2pl
understand all
‘Have you understood everything?’
Now, if arguments are DPs, it then follows that the quantifier tutta is a determiner.

Let us now turn to the issue of the internal structure of the DP consisting solely of the quantifier tutta. Although it is clear that the quantifier is the head, we may wonder whether it takes a null DP complement as represented in (119), or simply takes no complement, as in (120), i.e., the quantifier tutta is an intransitive determiner in this case:

(119)
a. [DP tutti pro] sanno leggere. (=118a)
b. Avete capito [DP tutti pro]? (=118b)

(120)
a. [DP tutti] sanno leggere. (=118a)
b. Avete capito [DP tutti]? (=118b)

The representation where the DP appears in subject position in (119a) is plausible, as Italian allows null subject pro. That in (119b) is much less so, since null object pronouns, in contrast with null subject pronoun, are restricted to having a plural, human antecedent in generic contexts (Rizzi 1986a). The context in the example in (119b) is clearly not generic, and the object need not have a human antecedent; it may refer to books. Hence, there cannot be an object pro in (118b). If this is correct, then the example in (118b) most naturally has the structure in (120b). (118a) can have the structure in (120a) as well.

If an appositive relative clause may appear as DP-adjunct, and a restrictive one as NP-adjunct (cf. Browning 1991; Law 1991b), then the fact that the quantifier tutto may co-occur with an appositive, but not with a restrictive relative clause (Cinque 1995b: 479) shows that the quantifier tutto heads the DP, i.e., it is an intransitive determiner in this case:

(121)
a. Ho preso tutto, che non era poi molto, e me ne sono andato, . . .
have.1sg
take everything which not be that much and myself of-it am go
‘I took everything, which was not that much, and I left.’
b. *Ho preso tutto che mi piaceva.
have.1sg
take everything that me please
‘I took everything I liked.’

The conclusion is further supported by facts about the French counterpart of tutto; French does not allow null arguments. As shown in (122), the quantifier tout/toutes/tous ‘all’ may appear without being followed by a DP (Grevisse 1986: 1157):

(122)
a. On peut s’attendre à tout. French
one can expect to all
‘One can expect everything.’
b. M. Gaston Deferre qui serre les mains de toutes et de tous.
Mr. Gaston Deferre who shake the hands of everyone.fem
and of everyone.masc
‘Mr. Gaston Deferre who shakes hands with everyone.’
Clearly, there is no reason to think that the DP consisting solely of the quantifier tout/toutes/tous ‘all’ takes a null pronoun as complement.

If the quantifier tutta in Italian and its counterpart in French are Ds, then we should expect them to be able to take an NP complement. The expectation is only partially borne out. French tout/toute/tous/toutes may take an NP complement, so may Italian mezza ‘half’, but tutta and entrambi/ambidue/ambo/ambe ‘both’ may not (Giorgi 1995: 300, Renzi 1995: 358):

(123)
Toute personne; toutes les personnes; tous (les) deux. French
all person all the persons all the two
‘All persons; all the people; both of them.’

(124)
a. mezza (la) faccia Italian
half the face
‘half (of) the face’
b. tutti *(i) ragazzi; tutta *(la) torta
all the boys all the tart
‘all the boys; all the tart’
c. entrambi *(i/quei) bambini; ambo/ambe *(le) mani
both the/those children both the hand
‘both children; both hands’
It is not clear why Italian tutta and entrambi/ambo/ambe differ from their French counterparts in obligatorily taking a DP-complement.

As for the structural relation between the quantifier and the following DP, there are a priori three possibilities. If the quantifier tutta heads the DP tutta la famiglia ‘the whole family’, then it either selects the following DP as complement as in (125a), or it projects a DP and the following DP adjoins to it, as in (125b):

(125)
a. [DP [tutta [DP la famiglia]]]
b. [DP [DP tutta] [DP la famiglia]]
