Alternatively, the DP tutta la famiglia is headed by the determiner la, and the quantifier tutta itself projects a DP and adjoins to the DP la famiglia. The representation for this last case would be just like (125b).

The structure in (125b) does not seem to be attested elsewhere, regardless of whether the first DP joins to the second, or the other way round. If it were possible, then we should expect DPs of the sort in (126) to be possible, contrary to fact:

(126)
a. *[[ la famiglia] [la riunione]]
the family the reunion
‘the family reunion’
b. *[[ il corso] [il texto]]
the course the text
‘the course text’

This leaves (125a) as the only possible structure for the DP tutta la famiglia where the quantifier tutta heads the whole DP. The lack of D-to-P incorporation in (116b) is now straightforward. Movement of the determiner la to P in the structure in (127) violates the HMC:
(127) *P+lai [DP [tutta [DP ti N]]]

It should be pointed out that although the example in (117a) does not bear on the account for (127) directly, there being no P-stranding, it is legitimate to ask why the structures and derivations given in (117), if they are correct, are possible at all; in particular, we may ask whether movement of the pronominal clitic in (117a) also violates the HMC, just like movement of the determiner in (127). The question is an important one, but is independent of P-stranding, as the same question also arises when the quantifier tutta is absent, i.e., the example in (117a) is grammatical without the quantifier. The pronominal clitic apparently moves across two lexical heads, and should violate the HMC, if it indeed undergoes head movement. The movement of the pronominal clitic in (117a) is then clearly related to a more general pattern, quite independently of the presence of the quantifier tutta. What needs to be explained is, although it remains unclear, why the structure in (117a) in Italian does not obey the constraint against stranding a left-modifier in German.

subsection.heading: 6.2 D-to-P incorporation from the specifier position
subsection.p: Van Riemsdijk (1998b: 659) points out that in some southern German varieties, a possessive pronoun may be preceded by a full DP in the dative Case, as in (128a) and (129a), whose head D may contract with a preceding preposition, as in (128b) and (128b):

(128)
a. von [[ dem Bürgermeister] [ seinem Gehalt]] German
of the.dat
mayor his.dat
salary
‘of the mayor's salary’
b. vom Bürgermeister seinem Gehalt

(129)
a. zu [[ der Prinzessin] [ihrem Palais]]
to the.dat
princess her.dat
palace
‘to the princess's palace’
b. zur Prinzessin ihrem Palais

Although it is not immediately obvious what structure the DP-complement of P has in these cases, it seems clear that the possessive pronoun is the head of the DP-complement of P, most evident in the Case form of the possessive pronoun when the DP complement appears as complement of verbs assigning different Cases (cf. the examples in (135) below). Now, if forming an X0 is a necessary condition for contraction, then the head D of the DP in the specifier must move to P, in violation of Ross's (1986) Left Branch Condition (LBC) barring movement of DP from the specifier position of a DP.
The problem is even more acute for the D-to-P incorporation analysis of P-stranding in cases like (130–131), where the D contracting with P is further embedded (Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 659):

(130)
a. von [[[ dem Hans] seiner Mutter] ihrem Geld] German
of the Hans his.dat
mother her.dat
money
‘of Hans's mother's money’
b. vom Hans seiner Mutter ihrem Geld

(131)
a. von [[[[ dem Hans] seiner Mutter] ihrem Freund] seinem Geld]
of the.dat
Hans his.dat
mother her.dat
friend his.dat
money
‘of Hans's mother's friend's money’
b. vom Hans seiner Mutter ihrem Freund seinem Geld

The contraction facts in (128–131) thus seem to suggest that the condition for contraction is purely phonological. That is, contraction of D and P is possible as long as they are adjacent. However, there is evidence showing that syntactic structure is relevant to contraction. As shown in (132–133), P and D may not contract, even though they are adjacent (Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 655):

(132)
a. von [DP [D e] [AP
dem König treu ergebenen] [N
Dienern]]
of the.dat
king faithfully devoted servants
‘of the servants faithfully devoted to the king’
b. *vom König treu ergebenen Dienern

(133)
a. zu [DP [D e] [AP
der Direktion zur Verfügung stellenden] [N Zimmern]]
to the.dat
board to availability put rooms
‘to the rooms made available to the board’
b. *zur Direktion zur Verfügung stellenden Zimmern

The obvious structural difference between (128–131) and (132–133) can be schematically represented as in (134a) and (134b) respectively (the DP in (134a) may be further embedded in the specifier of X):

(134)
a. P [XP [DP . . . D . . . ] [X . . . ]] (D-to-P incorporation possible)
b. P [XP [X [DP . . . D . . . ] . . . ]] (D-to-P incorporation impossible)

In terms of government, then, D is conceivably governed by P in (134a), but certainly not in (134b) where a head X intervenes between D and P (Chomsky 1986a; Rizzi 1990b). Van Riemsdijk (1998b: 660) suggests that accessibility for government is recursively defined to the effect that a lexical head may govern the specifier position of a complement, or a specifier position of a category further embedded in the specifier of the complement. Along these lines, then, the D head of the DP in the specifier in (134a) may move to P, but that in (134b) may not. In the latter case, the D is found inside a category that is too far to be governed by P.

While the D-to-P incorporation analysis of P-stranding is entirely compatible with such a view of government, there are certain empirical predictions that I cannot verify for lack of access to speakers and detailed descriptions of these varieties of German. If government is recursively defined across all lexical categories, then V in particular in the position of P in (134a) can govern D as well, just like P. V should also be able to govern the DP projection of D, and extraction of a DP from a specifier position of a DP should be possible, in violation of Ross's LBC:

(135)
a. Ich habe [[ dem Hans] [seinen [Vater]]] gesehen. German
I have the.dat
Hans his.acc
father seen
‘I saw Hans's father.’
b. [[Dem Hans] [seinen [Vater]]]i habej ich tj ti gesehen.
c. [Dem Hans]i habej ich tj [ti [seinen [Vater]]] gesehen.

(136)
a. Ich habe [[[ dem Hans] [seinem [Vater]]] [seinen [Chef]]] gesehen.
I have the.dat
Hans his.dat
father his.acc
boss seen
‘I saw Hans's father's boss.’
b. [[Dem Hans] [seinem [Vater]] [seinen [Chef]]]i habej ich tj ti gesehen.
c. [Dem Hans]i habej ich tj [ti [seinem [Vater]] [seinen [Chef]]] gesehen.

The structural relation between (the trace of) the finite verb and the DP in the specifier of the object in (135–136) is exactly the same as that between P and DP in (134a). Thus, the examples in (135c) and (136c) are very crucial to the theory of recursive government.

Unfortunately, I am not able to find speakers of the dialects allowing a full DP in the dative Case preceeding the possessive pronoun as in (128a) and (129a) to check whether the examples in (135c) and (136c) are possible. 30

subsection.heading: 7 Conclusion
subsection.p: I suggest to consider the suppletion facts involving Ps and Ds as evidence for Ds incorporating into Ps. A direct consequence of incorporation is that the incorporated head no longer forms a syntactic constituent with its complement, and hence may not move together with it. On this view, P-stranding does not depend on any specific assumption, such as canonical government or a reanalysis rule for V and P. Intuitively, then, P-stranding is simply the result of movement of the DP object of P. So if P and its DP object are not separable for some independent reason, then the lack of P-stranding follows immediately.

As P-stranding is simply the result of movement, it is irrelevant whether the movement is to an argument position, A-movement, or to a non-argument position, A-bar-movement. The difference between English on the one hand and other Germanic languages on the other with respect to P-passive does not warrant treating P-stranding differently in terms of A- vs. A-bar-movement. The difference can readily be accounted for by the independent Case-absorption property of the passive morpheme, which manifests itself in the impersonal passive construction independently from P-stranding.

Quite obviously, the accounts discussed above are adequate only to the extent that the empirical facts they bring to bear are correctly captured. It is almost certain that they will need to be revised when we consider languages with radically different grammatical properties. For instance, many Slavic and Asian languages have no determiner; yet, they disallow P-stranding. In fact, P-stranding is rather uncommon cross-linguistically, a fact that no theory of P-stranding to date is able to explain. To achieve explanatory adequacy, linguistic theory must capture this fact.

subsection.heading: NOTES
subsection.p: I am indebted to two very helpful anonymous reviewers for their extremely insightful comments and criticisms. Parts of section 5 have been presented at Friedrich-Schiller-Universität, Jena, May 1997 and at the North Eastern Linguistics Society Conference, University of Toronto, October 1997. I would like to thank the participants in these two events, especially Henk van Riemsdijk, for discussing various issues with me, as well as Johanna Barddal, Jörg Dreyer, Andrea Moro, and Christer Platzack for their help with Icelandic, German, Italian, and Swedish. I assume responsibility for any error or inadequacy.

p.span: 1 According to King and Roberge (1990), Acadian French spoken in Prince Edward Island, Canada, allows relatively free stranding of Ps:

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Quoi-ce que tu as parlé hier à Jean de? Acadian French
what-it that you have talked yesterday to John about
‘What did you talk to John about yesterday?’
b. Robert a été parlé beaucoup de au meeting.
Robert has been talked a lot of at the meeting
‘Robert was talked about a lot at the meeting.’
Remarkably, it seems to allow P to be stranded in an adjunct domain sometimes, impossible in English:

(ii)
a. Quelle heure qu’elle a arrivé à?
what time that-she has arrived at
‘What time did she arrive?’
b *Qui-ce que tu as parti après avoir vu?
who that you have left after to-have seen
‘Who did you leave after having seen?’

Lack of access to more detailed description of the language prevents me from further discussing this dialect of French. I will also not discuss cases like (iii), which Zribi-Hertz (1984) argued involve a null pronoun rather than movement of the complement of P, as the apparently stranded P is in a syntactic island for extraction:

(iii)
a. Je connais bien cette valise, car je voyage avec. Colloquial French
I know well this suitcase because I travel with
‘I know this suitcase well, for I always travel with it.’
b. Ce banc, savez-vous qui doit sauter par-dessus.
this bench, know-you who must jump over
‘This bench, do you know who must jump over?’

p.span: 2 Frisian apparently permits extraction of non-R-pronouns under A- and A-bar-movement, impossible in German and Dutch (Hoekstra 1995: 97):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Wa hast mei pratt? Frisian
who have.2sg
with talk
‘Who have you talked with?’
b. Hokker kandidaat stimme jimme op?
which candidate vote you for?
‘Which candidate are you voting for?’

(ii)
a. De bern wurdt net nei harke.
the children is not to listen
‘The children were not listened to.’
b. Elkenien hat er in foto fan makke.
everyone has he a picture of make
‘Has he made a picture of everyone?’

However, Hoekstra argues that the complements of P in (i) and (ii) are not extracted out of PP, but are base-generated in [Spec, CP], with the object of P being a phonetically empty resumptive pronoun, which may be overt when it and its antecedent are not in the same clause (Hoekstra 1995: 116):

(iii)
Hokker famkei
miendest dat er sei
which girl thought-you that he said
dat er mei hari /deri
met praat hie?
that he with her/there with talked had
‘Which girl did you think that he said that he had talked with?’

Hoekstra's analysis predicts that the stranded P may not lie in a syntactic island, e.g., an adjunct, as the object of P is not moved out of PP. Lack of access to Frisian speakers prevents me from verifying this prediction.

p.span: 3 The example in (17b) may be derived from (ia) by deleting the portion of the sentence lying between the wh-phrase and the P taking it as its argument, i.e., deleting the material inside the parentheses, a non-constituent (Ross 1969b):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. John left, but I don't who know (he went out) with.
b. *John left, but I don't who know with (he went out).

Notice that (ia) is independently possible with the material inside the parentheses present, so the structure in (17b) does not seem implausible, apart from the issue of deleting a non-constituent. The problem is the structure in (17a), since it would have to be derived, implausibly, from the ungrammatical example in (ib). An additional problem for the deletion account of Sluicing is that it does not explain why non-bare wh-phrases are impossible in the Sluice, as the examples in (18) show.

p.span: 4 A similar problem arises in French for the HC as well. If the I position is filled with the verb in embedded clauses, then extraction of the object in (i) should be impossible, according to the HC, since the head of the VP is not empty:

subsection.p:
(i)
Je me demande [CP
quii
[[IP
tu [as [VP
vu ti ]]]. French
I myself ask who
you have seen
‘I wonder who you saw.’

One way to get around this problem would be to allow adjunction to the intervening maximal projections (Chomsky 1986a). But new problems arise. One needs to independently justify the landing sites, given the SPC, and explain why such adjunction is not available for extraction out of PPs.

p.span: 5 A reviewer points out that some speakers accept Hornstein and Weinberg's example (30a). It is not clear, however, whether there are other dialectal differences bearing on this example.

6 Anderson (1977: 373) argues that passives of apparent objects of Ps are possible just when the object in question has been affected by the action or has acquired some characteristics as a result of it. The grammatical contrast in (i) is thus presumbly due to the bed in (ia) but not New York in (ib) being affected by the act of sleeping or having acquired some characteristics as a result of sleeping, as noted by Hornstein and Weinberg (1981: 88) (see also Baltin and Postal 1996):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. The bed was slept in.
b. *New York was slept in.
But the grammatical contrast between in (ii) and (33b) clearly does not fall under this account:
(ii) The carpet was repeatedly stepped on.
The only difference between them is the position of the adverb, and there is no reason to think that the carpet in the two examples has different properties in terms of affectedness.

p.span: 7 H. van Riemdijk (p.c.) points out that extraction of the sort in (37) may be consistent with the excorporation analysis of Roberts (1991a) in that V first incorporates into P and then V excorporates from the V+P complex to the second position. But this does not explain why V and P fail to behave like a syntactic unit.

8 One may conceivably argue that the subject trace is antecedent-governed by the trace in [Spec, CP], but this does not seem to be a possible solution in Kayne's analysis, as he explicitly states that movement into COMP is necessary in French to bring the embedded subject NP into a position close enough to V that V can govern it (Kayne 1984a: 112), apparently implying that head-government (Rizzi 1990b; Law 1991a) is required for traces. A possible solution of the government problem in (50) is to assume that French P-complementizers have no Case property, explaining why the embedded subject in (42) may not be overt, but nevertheless govern the embedded subject position, given that in (50) is grammatical. It may also be that the wh-phase in (50) moves through a Case position in the matrix clause, e.g., [Spec, AgrO] (cf. Chomsky 1991).

9 I assume here that negation is a VP-adjunct and that the R-pronoun er and the non-R-pronoun hem in (53) adjoin to the VP as well. The discussion in the text requires no changes if these assumptions turn out to be incorrect, e.g., negation heads a functional projection (cf. Laka 1990). The point here is that R-pronouns may move out of PP, but non-R-pronouns may not. The landing site of the R-pronoun is an independent issue (cf. Kayne 1991).

10 Schaub (1979) gives an extensive list of the Verschmelzungsformen ‘fused forms’ for P+D in German (cf. also Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 653). For cases like (i), where Ps begin with a vowel, the leftmost R-pronouns are doubled with what looks like a pronoun da followed by a semivowel r (dar is preferably reduced to dr), the same phonological reduction seen in pairs like heraus vs. raus ‘from here’):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Wo besteht er dar-auf? German
what insists he it-on
‘What is he insisting on?’
b. Da habe ich dar-an gedacht.
it have I it-of thought
‘I have thought of it.’

The apparent doubling of the R-pronouns may suggest that both of them are base-generated in place, but as far as I can tell, the examples in (i) arguably involve movement of the R-pronoun wo or da, since the P may not lie inside a syntactic island. Wunderlich (1984: 96, n. 21) claims that the consonant d to the left of a preposition is the spell-out of the trace of the R-pronoun da (cf. Oppenrieder 1991a for an alternative view, however). It is unclear whether the doubling of the R-pronouns has significant syntactic consequences.

p.span: 11 A clear case in point is the English verbs in the present tense; most of them have the ending -s suffixed to the verb stem in third person singular (cf. work vs. works), while the rest have the same form as the verb stem. The remarkable exception is the copular verb be, which has several suppletive forms: am, is, are. There seems to be no generalization as to what kind of verbs undergo suppletion.

12 This assumption might seem unmotivated for Dutch, which has no D+P suppletive forms. As Dutch shares with German a large number of syntactic properties (syntax of verbs, scrambling, impersonal passives, etc.), it does not appear implausible that Dutch Ps may have the same properties as German Ps. The lack of suppletive forms for D+P in Dutch is not too surprising given the little morphology it has for other categories, e.g., Case morphologies on nouns, adjectives, and determiners.
13 In Italian (and Spanish) object pronominal clitics follow the non-finite verb or occur above the complementizer in cases of clitic climbing (cf. Rizzi 1982: 3–5):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Piero affermava di conoscer-la
molto bene. Italian
Peter stated of know-her very well
‘Peter stated that he knew her very well.’
b. Piero li
venne a chiamare stazione.
Peter them came to call station
‘Peter came to call them at the station.’
However, they never appear in a position from which it can incorporate into the P-complementizer.

p.span: 14 As a reviewer points out, a category inflected for number and gender is not necessarily of the category determiner, e.g., adjectives. But as the determiner is usually obligatory in Romance, the exceptions being cases like prend contact avec ‘to have contact with’ where the noun is a complement to a verb, it is quite plausible that French quel ‘which’ and Italian qual ‘which’ are determiners.

15 Müller (1991) argues that all XPs are barriers for extraction of the complement of X, but the barrierhood of XP can be voided if X incorporates into a higher head. P-stranding is thus possible if P incorporates into V abstractly, with the consequence that the Case-assigning capability (of the trace) if P is lost, and V with the incorporated P cannot take over the Case of P and assign it structurally to the object of P (Müller 1991: 191). As the formally invariant R-pronouns do not need Case, it follows that only these can be extracted out of PP when P incorporates abstractly into V.

subsection.p: Several problems arise in this analysis, however. First, there is no obvious reason for abstract incorporation of P into V. Second, to distinguish P incorporating into V with the subsequent loss of the Case assignment property and V incorporating into I without loss of the Case assignment property, Müller (1991: 180) assumes that lexical categories are opaque in that the Case property of the incorporated head is lost, while functional categories are transparent in that the incorporated head can still assign Case when it incorporates into a functional category. There is clearly no independent evidence for the lexical vs. functional category distinction regarding the Case property of the incorporated head. Third, intuitively, if a predicate assigns Case, then there must be a category that takes its Case (cf. Chomsky's 1995c feature-checking theory). In order to bring about the result that P cannot assign Case to its object when it incorporates into V, it must be assumed that V takes or checks the Case of P, for which there is apparently no independent motivation. Fourth, in a case like (i) where the PP moves to [Spec, CP] in main clause, P presumably cannot incorporate into V, because abstract (head) incorporation is subject to constraints on (head) movement:

(i)
Davon hat er geredet. German
it-from has he talked
‘He talked of it.’

The problem here is that the Case of the preposition von cannot be assigned or checked, the R-pronoun needing no Case. Fifth, as Müller (1991: 192, n. 26) notes, it must be assumed that as a parametric choice the trace of a P incorporated into V in English in p-passive can assign Case to its object, as full DPs needing Case may be extracted, stranding P. It is not clear whether this parametric choice is related to any other grammatical property.

p.span: 16 It is an independent issue whether R-pronouns originate in the Spec position or move from the complement position. On conceptual grounds, one might assume the latter so that all complements originate from the same position, despite there being no empirical evidence for R-pronouns originating in a position to the right of P.

17 Note that the examples in (77) by themselves do not show that the R-pronoun er is in [Spec, PP]; it might very well be in an adjoined position. What these examples do show, however, is that the R-pronoun does not incorporate into P. My analysis of P-stranding needs no modification if it turns out to be adjoined to PP.
18 A reviewer points out that the temporal P na ‘after’ may not be stranded, in contrast with the locative P achter ‘after’:

subsection.p:
(i)
Ik heb (*er) Jan (??er) vlak (er) na bezocht. Dutch
I have it Jan it right it after visited
‘I have visited Jan right after it.’
The PP erna in (i) seems to be an adjunct. Therefore, that er may not move out of the PP stranding P na (i) is plausibly due to Huang's CED, cf. the discussion of (38).

p.span: 19 The reason why an embedded clause is chosen in (83) is to abstract away from the verb-second effect. The example in (i) with a matrix clause obscures the position of the logical object of the verb Hans und Maria ‘Hans and Maria’. It is not immediately obvious that it is in subject position, i.e., [Spec, IP], even though it agrees with the finite verb:

subsection.p:
(i)
Es wurden/*wurde Hans und Maria getötet. German
it became.pl/*sg
Hans and Maria killed
‘Hans and Maria were killed.’

In most analyses, subject–finite verb agreement involves the configuration in which the finite verb is in I0, and the agreeing argument is in [Spec, IP]. It then follows that the expletive es (phonetically identical with the third person singular neutral nominative or accusative argument pronoun) is not in subject position. Moreover, the expletive es cannot appear in an embedded clause with an overt complementizer, indicating that the expletive es in (i) is most probably not in subject position:

(ii)
. . . , dass (*es) Hans und Maria getötet *wurde/wurden.
that it Hans and Maria
‘. . . that Hans and Maria were killed.’

p.span: 20 There is a complication with the example in (86a). The German third person pronoun da is formally invariant, regardless of the number, gender, and Case features. It is therefore not immediately clear that the grammatical version of (86a) with the verb in the singular shows that it really agrees with a singular da. The crucial point is that it cannot have the plural form, even when da has a plural antecedent, showing that the singular form of the verb is most likely the default form when it does not agree with an argument. Cf. the examples in (85).

21 The structures in (82) would be more closely parallel to those with wh-movement if they are represented as in (i), a kind of topicalization structure (Koster 1978d), where O is a phonetically null counterpart of an overt wh-phrase, known as the null operator (Chomsky 1982; Browning 1991):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Þessa kona [Oi
[er oftast talað vel [PP
um ti ]]]. Icelandic
that woman.acc
is usually spoken well of
‘The woman is usually spoken well of.’
b. Þennan ref [Oi
[hefur aldrei verið skotið [PP
á ti ]]].
that fox.acc
has never been shot at
‘That fox has never been shot at.’
It is not clear, however, why in structures in (i) the topicalized object has the Case assigned to the operator by P, even though it does not originate from the trace position.

p.span: 22 The term raising applying to both English and Icelandic here is unfortunate. A-movement is commonly taken to be Case-motivated, which is clearly true of English, but not of Icelandic (cf. the DPs with quirky Case that retain their Case even when they do not appear in the base-position).

23 As Baltin and Postal (1996: 142) point out, it is not always possible to have the P+V combinations in P-passive as prenominal modifiers (adding an adverbial like often or repeatedly in (ib) does not seem to improve grammaticality):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. The table was jumped/leaned/sat on.
b. *Jumped/leaned/sat on tables.
What needs to be explained is why the examples in (92) are possible, but those in (ib) are not, an issue that is independent of whether the P+V combinations are the results of reanalysis.

p.span: 24 Vikner (1995: 209–210) attributes the difference between English and other Germanic languages with respect to the impersonal passive construction to the different structural conditions under which Case is assigned in these languages. More specifically, he suggests that chains consisting of an expletive and a passive morpheme are subject to a condition according to which a chain not receiving a theta-role under government must receive Case under government. In his view, the passive morpheme in English is assigned a theta-role, but not under government, and the subject is assigned Case under Spec-I0 agreement. Thus, a chain consisting of the expletive and the passive morpheme in English is impossible, since the expletive in subject position is not assigned Case under government. By contrast, Case is assigned under government from C0 in verb-second languages; thus, a chain consisting of an expletive and a passive morpheme in the impersonal passive construction is always possible in these languages.

subsection.p: There are two problems with his analysis. First, it does not explain why an overt expletive is impossible in cases like (i):

(i)
a. Ist (*es) getanzt worden? German
is it danced become
‘Has there been dancing?’
b. *Hafur (*Það) verið dansað. Icelandic
has it been danced
‘Has there been dancing?’

Second, as Vikner also notes, his account does not explain why it is also impossible to embed the impersonal passive construction under an ECM verb in English, when the expletive is assigned Case under government.

(ii)
a. *I believe there to have been danced.
b. *Do you believe there to be have slept anybody here?

p.span: 25 There is an independent issue as to why an argument with Case moves, if movement must be motivated. I leave this issue open here.
26 The same conclusion holds of the examples in (i) (Maling and Zaenen 1985: 207):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Hennei /*honi
skrattades det [PP
åt ti ]. Swedish
her.acc/she.nom
was-laughed it at
‘She was laughed at.’
b. Hami /*hani
blev der leet [PP
ad ti ]. Danish
her.acc/she.nom
was it smiled at
‘She was smiled at.’

Many speakers prefer to retain the expletives det and der in (i) (Christer Platzack, p.c. and Allan et al. 1995: 161). Thus, the ungrammaticality of the examples in (ii) might very well be due to the absence of the expletive, rather than to lack of P-passive in these languages:

(ii)
a. *Honi
skrattades [PP
at ti ]. Swedish
she.nom
was-laughed at
‘She was laughed at.’
b. *Hani
blev leet [PP
ad ti ]. Danish
she.nom
was smiled at
‘She was smiled at.’

p.span: 27 Van Riemsdijk (1998b: 662, n. 40) notes that genau ‘exactly’ in (100) and knapp ‘nearly’ (101) are really adjectives, used adverbially. They are uninflected in this use, but must be inflected when used as adjectives. The form of the adjectival inflection depends on the number, gender and Case features of the modified noun (cf. the schwa on genau in das genaue Gegenteil ‘the exact opposite’). However, many, if not most, adjectives do not have the syntax of genau or knapp. As shown in (i), adjectives like klug ‘clever’, dumm ‘dumb’, ehrlich ‘frank’, and schön ‘nice’ may be used adverbially, but they cannot intervene between P and its DP-complement (note that klug in (id) modifies geredet ‘talk’, not Mann ‘man’, and that in (iid) schön modifies geantwortet ‘answer’, not Frage ‘question’):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Hans hat klug geredet. German
Hans has cleverly talked
‘Hans talked cleverly.’
b. Hans hat von dem klugen Mann geredet.
Hans has of the.dat
clever man talked
‘Hans talked of the clever man.’
c. *Hans hat von klug/klugen dem Mann geredet.
d. Hans hat klug/*klugen von dem Mann geredet.
‘Hans talked of the man cleverly.’

(ii)
a. Hans hat schön geantwortet.
Hans has nice answered
‘Hans answered nicely.’
b. Hans hat zu der schönen Frage geantwortet.
Hans has to the.dat
nice.dat
question answered
‘Hans answered the nice question.’
c. *Hans hat zu schön/schönen der Frage geantwortet.
d. Hans hat schön/*schönen zu der Frage geantwortet.
‘Hans answered the question nicely.’
It is not clear why adjectives like genau and knapp may have adverbial use but many others do not.

p.span: 28 Note that the degraded status of the example in (ia) is most probably due to independent factors, having to do with P being separated too far from the verb taking it as complement. The example becomes perfect if the relative clause occurs at the end of the sentence as in (ib) so that P and the verb are close together:

subsection.p:
(i)
a. ??Dai
hat Hans [ti
[von ti
[was uns übrigens auch interessiert]]] geredet. German
it has Hans
of what us by the way also interest talked
‘Hans talked of it, which by the way we are also interested in.’
b. Dai hat Hans [ti [von ti ] tj ] geredet [was uns übrigens auch interessiert]j .
A similar grammatical contrast holds of the examples in (ii) where there is no P-stranding:

(ii)
a. ?Da hat Hans von diesem Thema, was/das uns übrigens auch interessiert, geredet.
German
there has Hans of this topic what/that us by the way also interest talked
‘There Hans talked of this topic, which we are by the way also interested in.’
b. Da hat Hans von diesem Thema geredet, was/das uns übrigens auch interessiert.
The slight grammatical difference between (ia) and (iia) is perhaps due to the already (slightly) marginal status of P-stranding.

p.span: 29 It is worth noting that according to Rizzi (1995: 515) contraction with con ‘with’ is optional, in contrast with the pair in (i) given by Van Riemsdijk (1998b: 663):

subsection.p:
(i)
*con la famiglia vs. colla famiglia. Italian
with the family
Renzi (1995: 410) also gives the example in (ii) where con is not contracted with the following determiner:

(ii)
Ho comprato un quadro con la cornice. Italian
have bought a picture with the frame
‘I bought a picture with the frame.’
The problem remains as to why the example in (116b) is ungrammatical.

p.span: 30 In (European) Portuguese, a prepositional complementizer may contract with the D of the following subject (Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 660–661):

subsection.p:
(i)
a. Eu entrei depois do/*de o meu pai chagar do escritorio. Portuguese
I entered after of-the/of the my father arrive from-the office
b. Antes da/*de a chuvada estalar no pavimento, entrou pela vila [ . . . ] uma charrete.
before of-the/of the downpour to-rattle in-the soil there-entered in-the village
a barrow
As subject it can at least sometimes be extracted (Zubizarreta 1982b: 82):

(ii)
a. Que rapazesi
acreditas que ti
tenham gasto esse dinheiro?
which children believe.2sg
that have spent that money
‘Which children do you believe spent that money?’
b. Que rapazesi
desconfia a policia que ti
tenham roubado aquela loja?
which children suspect the police that have broken into-that house
‘Which children does the police suspect broke into that house?’
The D-to-P incorporation as indicated by the P+D contraction in (i) is not totally surprising since the subject in (i) is governed in whatever way the subject in (ii) is.

Subject extraction out of an inflected infinitival, of which the examples in (i) are instances, are not always possible, however. In particular, the subject of an inflected factive infinitival complement may not be extracted (Zubizarreta 1982b: 82):

(iii)
a. *Quemi
preocupa-te ti
terem gasto esse dinheiro?
who worries-you have.inf.3.pl
spent that money
‘Who worries you in having spent that money?’
b. *Que meninosi
é que tu lamentas ti
terem roubado aquela loja?
which children be that you regret have.inf.3.pl
broken into that house
‘Which children is it that you regret to have broken into that house?’

At first glance, the ungrammaticality of the examples in (iii) is quite unexpected. If P may govern D in (i), allowing D to move to P, then there is no reason why the matrix V in (iii) may not. The problem is aggravated by the fact that object may be extracted out of an inflected factive infinitival complement. The example in (iv) is only slightly degraded (Zubizarreta 1982b: 82):

(iv)
?Que lojai
é que tu lamentas os meninos terem roubado ti ?
which house be that you regret the children have.inf.3.pl
break
‘Which house is it that you regret the children broke into?’

Zubizarreta (1982b: 88) suggests that movement to the Comp (=[Spec, CP]) of a factive complement is not possible, as a factive clause projects a nominal Comp (not represented in (iii)). Being governed by the verb, the object may move directly to the matrix clause, an option that is not available to the subject, since the verb does not govern it. But a subject can move out of a non-factive complement since its Comp is available as an escape hatch. The trace of the extracted phrase in subject position is presumably governed by the trace in Comp (Lasnik and Saito 1984).

Nevertheless, the government-based account for P-stranding in (i) cannot rely on Zubizarreta's analysis since there is no trace in Comp to govern the DP in subject position out of which D moves to P. It must be assumed that it is P that governs the subject. Notice that the examples in (iii) lack a complementizer, their ungrammaticality is thus expected under this account.

It should be emphasized that P does not always contract with the D head of a DP subject of an infinitive (cf. Longa 1994, cited in Van Riemsdijk 1998b: 660, n. 38). In fact, Caetano et al. (1986: 113) give some examples where P does not contract with D, in contrast with (i):

(v)
a. Não há perigo de as crianças se perderem. Portuguese
not have danger of the children self lose
‘There is no danger of the children getting lost.’
b. Não pude sair, por o tempo estar mau.
not could go out because the weather be bad
‘I couldn't go out, because the weather is bad.’
They mention explicitly that P does not contract with a following article that is part of a subject.
